candidates.title_1: Emergent structures in coupled opinion and network dynamics
candidates.title_2: Advancing Opinion Dynamics Modeling with Neural Diffusion-Convection-Reaction Equation
candidates.mechanism_1: Individuals' opinions and network edge weights coevolve through coupled dynamics. Interaction strength depends on opinion distance. Similar opinions strengthen network connections. Connection strength amplifies opinion influence. This creates feedback between opinion convergence and network structure formation. Interaction function form determines emergent structures and stability.
candidates.mechanism_2: Opinion evolution emerges from three coupled processes: diffusion (local influence spreading), convection (directional opinion flow driven by global trends), and reaction (endogenous opinion change). Each level operates at distinct scales—local peer-to-peer, global population-wide, and individual internal—that interact through multi-scale coupling. The system exhibits dynamics from interacting particle theory projected onto opinion space.

candidates.title_1: A theory for coexistence and selection of branched actin networks in a shared and finite pool of monomers
candidates.title_2: Thermodynamic Limits of Physical Intelligence
candidates.mechanism_1: Local monomer depletion from network growth creates negative feedback between network density and growth rate. Higher density causes faster monomer consumption and slower growth. Multiple networks sharing finite monomer pool reach steady states through self-regulation. Under strong competition, coexistence transitions to selection.
candidates.mechanism_2: Local monomer depletion creates negative feedback between network density and growth. Epiplexity (structural information encoding) and empowerment (control capacity) provide recognition vs. control axes for physical intelligence. Landauer-scale closed-cycle benchmarks require explicit boundary-closure and reset assumptions - without charging for external low-entropy resources, information gain and dissipation decouple.

candidates.title_1: A phenomenological description of critical slowing down at period-doubling bifurcations
candidates.title_2: Heterogeneity dominates irreversibility in random Markov models
candidates.mechanism_1: As a system approaches a bifurcation point, convergence to steady state slows dramatically. Near criticality, relaxation time diverges according to universal scaling laws. The system exhibits characteristic critical exponents that govern short-time behavior, asymptotic decay, and crossover between regimes.
candidates.mechanism_2: Markov dynamics combine heterogeneity and asymmetry (broken detailed balance). Heterogeneity parameter controls transition rate variability. Asymmetry parameter controls forward-backward correlation. Critical locus emerges where relaxation times diverge. Entropy production and predictive information depend strongly on heterogeneity but weakly on asymmetry. Near criticality, small heterogeneity changes cause large dynamical shifts.

candidates.title_1: From Discrete to Continuous Mixed Populations of Conformists, Nonconformists, and Imitators
candidates.title_2: FinEvo: From Isolated Backtests to Ecological Market Games for Multi-Agent Financial Strategy Evolution
candidates.mechanism_1: Three behavioral types interact: conformists benefit from choosing common strategies, nonconformists profit from rare strategies, and imitators copy highest earners. Population proportions fluctuate in finite populations but equilibrate as population size increases. Strategy proportions undergo perpetual oscillations in small populations, but fluctuation amplitudes approach zero in large populations through stochastic averaging.
candidates.mechanism_2: Strategy distributions evolve through selection (performance-based survival), innovation (mutation), and environmental perturbation (external shocks). Individual agents adapt using local signals while population composition shifts based on relative fitness. Two-layer adaptation - individual learning plus population-level evolution - determines whether strategies persist, collapse, or form coalitions.

candidates.title_1: Discrete dynamical systems with scaling and inversion symmetries
candidates.title_2: Chaotic Dynamics in Extremal Black Holes: A Challenge to the Chaos Bound
candidates.mechanism_1: System state evolves discretely through iterated function. Scaling symmetry preserves dynamics under magnification/contraction. Near fixed points, small perturbations grow exponentially (positive Lyapunov exponent) causing sensitive dependence. Trajectories confined to fractal attractor with non-integer dimension. Chaotic regime characterized by scaling laws and self-similarity across scales.
candidates.mechanism_2: Particle motion in extremal configurations exhibits positive Lyapunov exponents indicating sensitivity to initial conditions. Chaos persists even at zero temperature. System parameters (spin, charge) modulate chaos strength - increasing one parameter strengthens chaotic behavior while the other weakens it.

candidates.title_1: Normative Equivalence in Human-AI Cooperation: Behaviour, Not Identity, Drives Cooperation in Mixed-Agent Groups
candidates.title_2: Indirect Reciprocity with Environmental Feedback
candidates.mechanism_1: Reciprocal group dynamics and behavioral inertia drive cooperation levels in groups. Cooperation depends on observed group behavior patterns rather than the identity of participants. These normative mechanisms operate identically regardless of agent type, creating stable cooperation patterns through behavioral feedback.
candidates.mechanism_2: Individual behaviors shape reputation through social norms while simultaneously affecting collective resource levels. Environmental changes alter payoff structures, creating feedback between strategic behavior and resource dynamics. Reputation-based cooperation interacts with ecological constraints - cooperative behaviors deplete or enhance shared resources, which then reshape the incentives for future cooperation.

candidates.title_1: Strategic Interactions in Science and Technology Networks: Substitutes or Complements?
candidates.title_2: Mean-Field Price Formation on Trees with a Network of Relative Performance Concerns
candidates.mechanism_1: An agent's position in a collaboration network determines their productivity. Higher network centrality increases output through strategic complementarities with connected agents. Activity in one domain (scientific) enhances productivity in another domain (technological), but this effect is asymmetric - the reverse direction shows no detectable influence.
candidates.mechanism_2: Agents care about their performance relative to connected peers. Relative performance concerns create strategic interdependencies through network links. Risk-taking behavior adjusts based on peer comparisons. Network topology determines how competitive pressures propagate. This peer comparison mechanism affects equilibrium asset prices through aggregated strategic adjustments.

candidates.title_1: FSCA-Net: Feature-Separated Cross-Attention Network for Robust Multi-Dataset Training
candidates.title_2: PhageMind: Generalized Strain-level Phage Host Range Prediction via Meta-learning
candidates.mechanism_1: Feature disentanglement into domain-invariant and domain-specific components mitigates negative transfer in multi-dataset training. Cross-attention fusion adaptively models component interactions. Mutual information optimization maximizes domain-invariant consistency while minimizing domain-specific redundancy. Complementary shared-private representations enable knowledge transfer while preserving dataset-specific discriminability.
candidates.mechanism_2: Transfer learning with structured graph representations enables few-shot adaptation across related domains by identifying shared interaction principles from well-studied systems and rapidly adapting to new contexts with minimal training data.

candidates.title_1: Mean-Field Price Formation on Trees with a Network of Relative Performance Concerns
candidates.title_2: The Architecture of Illusion: Network Opacity and Strategic Escalation
candidates.mechanism_1: Agents care about their performance relative to connected peers. Relative performance concerns create strategic interdependencies through network links. Risk-taking behavior adjusts based on peer comparisons. Network topology determines how competitive pressures propagate. This peer comparison mechanism affects equilibrium asset prices through aggregated strategic adjustments.
candidates.mechanism_2: Network-mediated observation bias creates systematic misperception in strategic reasoning. Agents observe only network-local sample biased by position (algorithmic ranking, homophily), not global population. Locality parameter controls observation bias magnitude, creating distorted beliefs about opponent sophistication that drive strategic escalation beyond what accurate global information would produce.

candidates.title_1: A Minimal Task Reveals Emergent Path Integration and Object-Location Binding in a Predictive Sequence Model
candidates.title_2: DreamDojo: A Generalist Robot World Model from Large-Scale Human Videos
candidates.mechanism_1: Action-conditioned sequential prediction enables path integration and dynamic object-location binding for world modeling. Prediction accuracy improves across sequence through in-context learning. Structured representations with flexible binding emerge to support prediction - new bindings learnable late in sequence, out-of-distribution bindings acquirable through sequential exposure.
candidates.mechanism_2: Continuous latent actions serve as unified proxy actions, enabling interaction knowledge transfer from unlabeled human videos to robot control. World model learns diverse interactions from 44k hours of egocentric video. Post-training on small-scale robot data yields physics understanding and precise action controllability. Generative modeling enables teleoperation, policy evaluation, and planning.

candidates.title_1: Decoupling Variance and Scale-Invariant Updates in Adaptive Gradient Descent for Unified Vector and Matrix Optimization
candidates.title_2: Muon in Associative Memory Learning: Training Dynamics and Scaling Laws
candidates.mechanism_1: Decomposing AdaGrad into variance adaptation and scale-invariant terms creates unified framework bridging vector-based and matrix spectral optimization. Variance adaptation improves blockwise smoothness for faster convergence. Decoupling enables seamless transition from coordinate-wise adaptation (Adam) to spectral descent (Muon) by separating second-order correction from coordinate scaling.
candidates.mechanism_2: Sign-based gradient transformation equalizes learning rates across hierarchical frequency components by removing magnitude dependence, eliminating bottlenecks from low-frequency modes and enabling exponentially faster convergence.

candidates.title_1: Normative Equivalence in Human-AI Cooperation: Behaviour, Not Identity, Drives Cooperation in Mixed-Agent Groups
candidates.title_2: Division of labor enables efficient collective decision-making under uncertainty
candidates.mechanism_1: Reciprocal group dynamics and behavioral inertia drive cooperation levels in groups. Cooperation depends on observed group behavior patterns rather than the identity of participants. These normative mechanisms operate identically regardless of agent type, creating stable cooperation patterns through behavioral feedback.
candidates.mechanism_2: Division of labor emerges from heterogeneous response thresholds combined with task-dependent positive feedback. Individuals with low thresholds specialize in corresponding tasks as they activate more frequently and self-reinforce. Threshold distribution determines whether population exhibits generalism or specialized subpopulations. Decentralized coordination through threshold heterogeneity without central control.

candidates.title_1: To clean or not to clean: The free-rider problem in sequentially shared resources
candidates.title_2: The impact of heterogeneity on the co-evolution of cooperation and epidemic spreading in complex networks
candidates.mechanism_1: Shared resource use creates a cooperation dilemma with cleaning costs, contamination risk, and social incentives forming competing pressures. Cleaning cost primarily determines stability of altruistic behavior. The system exhibits multi-stability and hysteresis - small parameter changes can cause abrupt shifts between cooperation and free-riding equilibria.
candidates.mechanism_2: Cooperation and disease transmission coevolve through network structure. Structural heterogeneity creates leverage points - highly connected hubs adopt protection due to amplified risk, catalyzing cooperation. Cost heterogeneity creates weakest links - low-risk individuals free-ride and act as disease reservoirs, undermining cooperation. Heterogeneity is double-edged: influence asymmetry facilitates cooperation, motivation asymmetry degrades it.

candidates.title_1: A phenomenological description of critical slowing down at period-doubling bifurcations
candidates.title_2: Numerical stationary states for nonlocal Fokker-Planck equations via fixed points of consistency maps
candidates.mechanism_1: As a system approaches a bifurcation point, convergence to steady state slows dramatically. Near criticality, relaxation time diverges according to universal scaling laws. The system exhibits characteristic critical exponents that govern short-time behavior, asymptotic decay, and crossover between regimes.
candidates.mechanism_2: Stationary states (both stable and unstable) are computed via fixed-point iteration of a consistency map derived from the PDE and nonlocal interactions. The method is agnostic to dynamical stability—detecting equilibria regardless of whether they attract or repel trajectories. This separates statics (equilibrium existence) from dynamics (stability), enabling discovery of unstable stationary configurations invisible to time-evolution methods.

candidates.title_1: Structure-aware imitation dynamics on higher-order networks
candidates.title_2: The Architecture of Illusion: Network Opacity and Strategic Escalation
candidates.mechanism_1: Higher-order network structure (beyond pairwise) shapes imitation dynamics through group-dependent adoption rates. Information diversity achieved through structured sampling from local neighborhoods. Adoption probability depends on group composition and size, not just neighbor count. Network hypergraph structure determines equilibrium strategy distributions through sampling bias.
candidates.mechanism_2: Network-mediated observation bias creates systematic misperception in strategic reasoning. Agents observe only network-local sample biased by position (algorithmic ranking, homophily), not global population. Locality parameter controls observation bias magnitude, creating distorted beliefs about opponent sophistication that drive strategic escalation beyond what accurate global information would produce.

candidates.title_1: DeXposure-FM: A Time-series, Graph Foundation Model for Credit Exposures and Stability on Decentralized Financial Networks
candidates.title_2: Impact of seed node position on network robustness under localized attacks
candidates.mechanism_1: Token-mediated dependencies create dense inter-component connections. A shock to one component propagates through dependency links causing contagion effects. Network topology and link weights determine the extent and path of cascading failures across the system.
candidates.mechanism_2: Localized damage initiates at a seed node and propagates to neighbors. The structural position of the seed node (local connectivity and topology) amplifies or dampens damage progression. Cumulative link severing during attack progression depends critically on seed node characteristics rather than average network properties.

candidates.title_1: Mean-Field Price Formation on Trees with a Network of Relative Performance Concerns
candidates.title_2: Game-Theoretic and Algorithmic Analyses of Multi-Agent Routing under Crossing Costs
candidates.mechanism_1: Agents care about their performance relative to connected peers. Relative performance concerns create strategic interdependencies through network links. Risk-taking behavior adjusts based on peer comparisons. Network topology determines how competitive pressures propagate. This peer comparison mechanism affects equilibrium asset prices through aggregated strategic adjustments.
candidates.mechanism_2: Crossing cost (product of opposing-direction agent counts) quantifies conflict risk in asynchronous multi-agent routing. Pure Nash equilibria exist when agents minimize individual crossing exposure. Equilibrium emergence dynamics depend on network structure - general case is PLS-complete, but polynomial-time solvable under mild structural conditions.

candidates.title_1: Habitat heterogeneity and dispersal network structure as drivers of metacommunity dynamics
candidates.title_2: Cross-feeding yields high-dimensional chaos and coexistence of species beyond exclusion principle
candidates.mechanism_1: Spatial structure and dispersal networks jointly determine species persistence. Heterogeneous habitats support stable coexistence only above a critical heterogeneity threshold. Homogeneous environments allow coexistence only in a fine-tuned marginal state, creating instability. Network topology encodes dispersal effectiveness through an effective kernel.
candidates.mechanism_2: Species cross-feed through metabolite leakage and uptake. Competitive uptake of leaked chemicals creates coupled population-chemical dynamics. Network structure determines attractor types: fixed points, limit cycles, low-dimensional chaos, or high-dimensional chaos. High-dimensional chaos enables coexistence beyond competitive exclusion limits through intermittent switching among quasi-stationary states. Chemical dynamics explore high-dimensional space while populations switch intermittently.

candidates.title_1: To clean or not to clean: The free-rider problem in sequentially shared resources
candidates.title_2: Thermodynamic cost-controllability tradeoff in metabolic currency coupling
candidates.mechanism_1: Shared resource use creates a cooperation dilemma with cleaning costs, contamination risk, and social incentives forming competing pressures. Cleaning cost primarily determines stability of altruistic behavior. candidates.mechanism_2: Controllability-efficiency tradeoff in coupled resource management: independent regulation of multiple coupled resources requires balanced abundances to prevent cross-interference, but balanced states incur higher thermodynamic costs through increased entropy production.

candidates.title_1: From semantic memory to collective creativity: A generative cognitive foundation for social creativity models
candidates.title_2: Emergent structures in coupled opinion and network dynamics
candidates.mechanism_1: Individual semantic network topology determines ideational breadth. When agents exchange ideation traces, lower initial overlap predicts larger stimulation gains. Shared inspiration sources create network-level redundancy, forming feedback between individual cognitive structure and collective outcomes.

candidates.title_1: Optimal Harvesting in Stream Networks: Maximizing Biomass and Yield
candidates.title_2: Who sets the range? Funding mechanics and 4h context in crypto markets
candidates.mechanism_1: Resource stock accumulates from production flow. Exploitation (flow out) versus conservation (stock maintenance) tradeoff. Maximum sustainable yield occurs at intermediate stock level. Over-exploitation depletes stock below replenishment threshold causing collapse.
candidates.mechanism_2: Funding rates in perpetual futures impose economic costs on leveraged positions. High funding creates pressure to reduce directional exposure. Capital rebalancing occurs when funding costs exceed expected returns. Funding mechanisms act as negative feedback regulating trader behavior - extreme positions become economically unsustainable, creating mean-reverting pressure that defines trading ranges.

candidates.title_1: Social Catalysts, Not Moral Agents: The Illusion of Alignment in LLM Societies
candidates.title_2: Emulating Aggregate Human Choice Behavior and Biases with GPT Conversational Agents
candidates.mechanism_1: External behavioral anchors induce strategic compliance and cognitive offloading without genuine norm internalization: agents mimic anchor behavior locally to reduce cognitive load, but revert to self-interested behavior when anchors absent or unobservable.
candidates.mechanism_2: Cognitive biases shape decision-making through interaction with contextual factors. When cognitive load increases (complex dialogue), pre-existing biases amplify through reduced deliberative capacity. The bias magnitude is context-dependent: simple interactions suppress bias expression, while complex interactions magnify it by consuming cognitive resources that would otherwise moderate biased responses.

candidates.title_1: Strategic Interactions in Science and Technology Networks: Substitutes or Complements?
candidates.title_2: Disentangling Causal Importance from Emergent Structure in Multi-Expert Orchestration
candidates.mechanism_1: An agent's position in a collaboration network determines their productivity. Higher network centrality increases output through strategic complementarities with connected agents. Activity in one domain (scientific) enhances productivity in another domain (technological), but this effect is asymmetric - the reverse direction shows no detectable influence.
candidates.mechanism_2: Expert importance exhibits dual structure: relational importance (routing frequency, interaction centrality) diverges from intrinsic importance (causal influence via gradient attribution). Frequently-routed experts may act as structural hubs with limited functional impact, while sparsely-routed experts can be causally critical. Masking intrinsically-important experts causes disproportionate collapse in interaction topology compared to masking frequent peers, revealing hidden causal dependencies.

candidates.title_1: Optimal Learning-Rate Schedules under Functional Scaling Laws: Power Decay and Warmup-Stable-Decay
candidates.title_2: AEGPO: Adaptive Entropy-Guided Policy Optimization for Diffusion Models
candidates.mechanism_1: Phase transition in optimal strategy based on task difficulty regime. System exhibits qualitatively different behaviors (power decay vs warmup-stable-decay) separated by sharp threshold determined by ratio of signal learning rate to noise forgetting capacity. Easy-task regime benefits from gradual decay, hard-task regime requires maintaining peak resources until near completion.
candidates.mechanism_2: Dual-signal adaptive resource allocation using entropy as proxy for learning value. Global level: relative entropy change identifies high-value samples for prioritized exploration. Local level: absolute entropy peaks identify critical moments within each trajectory. Concentrates computation where information gain is highest rather than uniform distribution.

candidates.title_1: Controlling extreme events in neuronal networks: A single driving signal approach
candidates.title_2: Emergence and co-existence of periodic and unstructured motion in future-avoiding random walks
candidates.mechanism_1: A single driving signal applied to one network component suppresses extreme events throughout the system. In coupled components, drive breaks phase-locking between elements. In networked systems, drive disrupts protoevent frequency dynamics causing frequency decoupling that prevents extreme event cascades.
candidates.mechanism_2: Self-amplifying coupling to periodic components of stochastic forcing drives phase transition from unstructured to structured behavior: weak periodic signals in noise become amplified through positive feedback, spontaneously synchronizing system components.

Network dynamics alone soften combinatorial feasibility barriers without requiring specific biochemistry.

candidates.title_1: Optimal Control Strategies for Epidemic Dynamics: Integrating SIR-SI and Lotka--Volterra Models
candidates.title_2: Modeling tumor progression in heterogeneous microenvironments: A cellular automata approach
candidates.mechanism_1: Coupled multi-timescale dynamics with threshold-based control transition. Fast epidemiological process coupled to slow ecological oscillation, where amplitude of slow cycle determines disease persistence via threshold (ecological reproduction number). Natural control sufficient above threshold; below threshold requires engineered intervention to navigate both timescales simultaneously.
candidates.mechanism_2: Environmental state dominates progression dynamics over intrinsic mutation rates in spatially structured systems: supportive environments amplify weak growth signals into invasive spread, while inhibitory environments suppress even high-mutation populations.

candidates.title_1: The relationship between R&D spillovers and regional innovation: Licensing patents through royalties and the Stackelberg duopoly with subgame perfect Nash equilibrium

candidates.mechanism_2: Technology adoption spreads through spatial and network channels. candidates.title_2: Phase Transitions in Unsupervised Feature Selection

System exhibits qualitatively different behaviors (power decay vs warmup-stable-decay) separated by sharp threshold determined by ratio of signal learning rate to noise forgetting capacity. Easy-task regime benefits from gradual decay, hard-task regime requires maintaining peak resources until near completion.
candidates.mechanism_2: Phase transition between constrained (glass-like) and unconstrained (liquid-like) regimes identifies minimal informative feature sets: critical feature count where order-parameter distributions shift from bimodal to unimodal marks saturation of downstream task performance.

candidates.title_1: FinEvo: From Isolated Backtests to Ecological Market Games for Multi-Agent Financial Strategy Evolution

Individual agents adapt using local signals while population composition shifts based on relative fitness. Two-layer adaptation - individual learning plus population-level evolution - determines whether strategies persist, collapse, or form coalitions.
candidates.mechanism_2: Assigning mutation and crossover strategies independently to each individual at initialization and keeping them fixed creates persistent behavioral heterogeneity. Static individual-level diversity (no adaptation) cultivates search effectiveness especially with large populations. Communication-free construction enables intrinsic concurrency and efficient parallel execution.

candidates.title_1: FinEvo: From Isolated Backtests to Ecological Market Games for Multi-Agent Financial Strategy Evolution

candidates.title_1: Effect of higher-order interactions on noisy majority-rule dynamics with random group sizes
candidates.title_2: The quenched structured coalescent for diploid population models on finite graphs with large migrations and uneven offspring distributions
candidates.mechanism_1: Variable group sizes in majority-rule dynamics create heterogeneous influence through effective majority leverage. Rare large-group events can realign substantial population fractions. Critical threshold for independence depends on group-size distribution - heavy-tailed distributions enhance robustness to disorder through occasional macroscopic coordination events.
candidates.mechanism_2: Conditioning on rare large events (quenched dynamics) versus averaging over event realizations (annealed dynamics) yields qualitatively different limiting processes: quenched limits preserve event-specific structure, annealed limits smooth over variability.

candidates.title_1: All-Atom GPCR-Ligand Simulation via Residual Isometric Latent Flow
candidates.title_2: Equilibrium Propagation for Non-Conservative Systems
candidates.mechanism_1: Residual dynamics modeling via decoupling static topology from temporal fluctuations. System learns isometric latent representation preserving geometric constraints (static topology), then models temporal evolution via relative displacements anchored to initial structure rather than absolute coordinates. Separates invariant structural relationships from dynamic conformational changes, improving computational efficiency while maintaining physical fidelity.
candidates.mechanism_2: Augmented state space with corrective dynamics extends equilibrium-based learning to non-conservative systems: adding auxiliary variables and non-reciprocal correction terms to learning dynamics recovers exact gradients despite broken energy conservation.

candidates.title_1: Emergence and co-existence of periodic and unstructured motion in future-avoiding random walks
candidates.title_2: Full-Covariance Chemical Langevin Predator--Prey Diffusion with Absorbing Boundaries
candidates.mechanism_1: Self-amplifying coupling to periodic components of stochastic forcing drives phase transition from unstructured to structured behavior: weak periodic signals in noise become amplified through positive feedback, spontaneously synchronizing system components.
candidates.mechanism_2: Predation creates event-level coupling through biomass conversion: predation-conversion increment (-1,+1) induces strictly negative cross-covariance between prey and predator populations. This mechanistic coupling cannot be captured by diagonal (independent) noise. The coupled dynamics arise from the irreducible stochastic structure of predation events, where prey loss simultaneously causes predator gain, creating intrinsic negative correlation in population fluctuations.

candidates.title_1: The impact of heterogeneity on the co-evolution of cooperation and epidemic spreading in complex networks
candidates.title_2: Game-Theoretic and Algorithmic Analyses of Multi-Agent Routing under Crossing Costs
candidates.mechanism_1: Cooperation and disease transmission coevolve through network structure. The system exhibits characteristic critical exponents that govern short-time behavior, asymptotic decay, and crossover between regimes.
candidates.mechanism_2: Qualitative phase transition via spectral condensation at criticality. Progressive reentrant coupling drives system toward infrared critical regime where extensive band of slow collective modes emerges (spectral condensation), reorganizing dynamics qualitatively. Creates emergent capabilities absent at subcritical regime - transition in kind not degree, regardless of system scale.

candidates.title_1: Optimal Control Strategies for Epidemic Dynamics: Integrating SIR-SI and Lotka--Volterra Models
candidates.title_2: Impact of behavioral heterogeneity on epidemic outcome and its mapping into effective network topologies

Natural control sufficient above threshold; below threshold requires engineered intervention to navigate both timescales simultaneously.
candidates.mechanism_2: Behavioral heterogeneity with homophily creates resurgence dynamics near critical thresholds: diverse risk responses combined with preferential interaction among similar types produces initial decline followed by secondary surge as low-risk subpopulation becomes infected.

candidates.title_1: Optimal Control Strategies for Epidemic Dynamics: Integrating SIR-SI and Lotka--Volterra Models

candidates.title_2: Numerical stationary states for nonlocal Fokker-Planck equations via fixed points of consistency maps

Asymmetry parameter controls forward-backward correlation. Critical locus emerges where relaxation times diverge. candidates.title_2: Optimal Control Strategies for Epidemic Dynamics: Integrating SIR-SI and Lotka--Volterra Models
candidates.mechanism_1: Microbes adapt to food supply while experiencing death. Oscillations emerge when adaptation timescale exceeds death timescale. Consumer-resource dynamics couple population growth to substrate replenishment. Multiple timescale interactions determine stability - slow adaptation relative to death enables oscillatory behavior. Necromass recycling and complementary food sources dampen oscillations by facilitating growth.
candidates.mechanism_2: Coupled multi-timescale dynamics with threshold-based control transition. Fast epidemiological process coupled to slow ecological oscillation, where amplitude of slow cycle determines disease persistence via threshold (ecological reproduction number). Natural control sufficient above threshold; below threshold requires engineered intervention to navigate both timescales simultaneously.

candidates.title_1: Estimating measures of information processing during cognitive tasks using functional magnetic resonance imaging
candidates.title_2: Learning to Share: Selective Memory for Efficient Parallel Agentic Systems
candidates.mechanism_1: Active information storage (within-region retention), transfer entropy (directed flow), and net synergy (redundancy vs. synergy) quantify information processing. Cross mutual information combines resting-state and task data to address limited samples. AIS increases with cognitive load in fronto-parietal regions; TE reveals enhanced directed flows; net synergy shows global redundancy shift.
candidates.mechanism_2: Learned selective information sharing across parallel exploration processes. Multiple independent teams explore different solution trajectories with learned controller deciding which intermediate results to place in globally-accessible shared memory. Balances exploration diversity (parallel independence) against computational efficiency (reuse of overlapping sub-solutions), using stepwise credit assignment to identify globally useful information.

candidates.title_1: Normative Equivalence in Human-AI Cooperation: Behaviour, Not Identity, Drives Cooperation in Mixed-Agent Groups
candidates.title_2: Structure-aware imitation dynamics on higher-order networks
candidates.mechanism_1: Reciprocal group dynamics and behavioral inertia drive cooperation levels in groups. These normative mechanisms operate identically regardless of agent type, creating stable cooperation patterns through behavioral feedback.
candidates.mechanism_2: Higher-order network structure (beyond pairwise) shapes imitation dynamics through group-dependent adoption rates. Information diversity achieved through structured sampling from local neighborhoods. Adoption probability depends on group composition and size, not just neighbor count. Network hypergraph structure determines equilibrium strategy distributions through sampling bias.

candidates.title_1: All-Atom GPCR-Ligand Simulation via Residual Isometric Latent Flow
candidates.title_2: PhysicsAgentABM: Physics-Guided Generative Agent-Based Modeling
candidates.mechanism_1: Residual dynamics modeling via decoupling static topology from temporal fluctuations. System learns isometric latent representation preserving geometric constraints (static topology), then models temporal evolution via relative displacements anchored to initial structure rather than absolute coordinates. Separates invariant structural relationships from dynamic conformational changes, improving computational efficiency while maintaining physical fidelity.
candidates.mechanism_2: Population-level inference with uncertainty-aware fusion decouples global dynamics from individual variability: clustering behaviorally similar entities, encoding mechanistic priors, and fusing uncertain predictions at cluster level enables scalable simulation.

candidates.title_1: Mean-Field Price Formation on Trees with a Network of Relative Performance Concerns
candidates.title_2: Threshold Resource Redistribution in Spatially-Structured Kinship Networks
candidates.mechanism_1: Agents care about their performance relative to connected peers. Relative performance concerns create strategic interdependencies through network links. Risk-taking behavior adjusts based on peer comparisons. Network topology determines how competitive pressures propagate. This peer comparison mechanism affects equilibrium asset prices through aggregated strategic adjustments.
candidates.mechanism_2: Threshold-based resource redistribution creates feedback between network structure and resource allocation ability. Agents below threshold solicit help; helpers contribute fractionally based on relatedness. Higher local density and relational closeness emerge as redistribution-dependent survival creates centralized clusters through cooperative resource sharing.

candidates.title_1: From Discrete to Continuous Mixed Populations of Conformists, Nonconformists, and Imitators
candidates.title_2: Social Catalysts, Not Moral Agents: The Illusion of Alignment in LLM Societies
candidates.mechanism_1: Three behavioral types interact: conformists benefit from choosing common strategies, nonconformists profit from rare strategies, and imitators copy highest earners. Strategy proportions undergo perpetual oscillations in small populations, but fluctuation amplitudes approach zero in large populations through stochastic averaging.
candidates.mechanism_2: External behavioral anchors induce strategic compliance and cognitive offloading without genuine norm internalization: agents mimic anchor behavior locally to reduce cognitive load, but revert to self-interested behavior when anchors absent or unobservable.

candidates.title_2: Heterogeneity dominates irreversibility in random Markov models

candidates.title_1: Collaboration for the Bioeconomy -- Evidence from Innovation Output in Sweden, 1970-2021
candidates.title_2: From semantic memory to collective creativity: A generative cognitive foundation for social creativity models
candidates.mechanism_1: Firms collaborate forming innovation network. Central firms access diverse knowledge from multiple partners enhancing innovation output. Peripheral firms limited by fewer connections. Network structure (centrality) determines innovation capacity. Successful innovators attract more partners (preferential attachment) reinforcing centrality advantage.
candidates.mechanism_2: Individual semantic network topology determines ideational breadth. When agents exchange ideation traces, lower initial overlap predicts larger stimulation gains. Shared inspiration sources create network-level redundancy, forming feedback between individual cognitive structure and collective outcomes.

candidates.title_1: Heterogeneity dominates irreversibility in random Markov models
candidates.title_2: Numerical stationary states for nonlocal Fokker-Planck equations via fixed points of consistency maps
candidates.mechanism_1: Markov dynamics combine heterogeneity and asymmetry (broken detailed balance). Heterogeneity parameter controls transition rate variability. Asymmetry parameter controls forward-backward correlation. Critical locus emerges where relaxation times diverge. Entropy production and predictive information depend strongly on heterogeneity but weakly on asymmetry. Near criticality, small heterogeneity changes cause large dynamical shifts.
candidates.mechanism_2: Stationary states (both stable and unstable) are computed via fixed-point iteration of a consistency map derived from the PDE and nonlocal interactions. The method is agnostic to dynamical stability—detecting equilibria regardless of whether they attract or repel trajectories. This separates statics (equilibrium existence) from dynamics (stability), enabling discovery of unstable stationary configurations invisible to time-evolution methods.

candidates.title_1: A Minimal Task Reveals Emergent Path Integration and Object-Location Binding in a Predictive Sequence Model
candidates.title_2: All-Atom GPCR-Ligand Simulation via Residual Isometric Latent Flow
candidates.mechanism_1: Action-conditioned sequential prediction enables path integration and dynamic object-location binding for world modeling. Prediction accuracy improves across sequence through in-context learning. Structured representations with flexible binding emerge to support prediction - new bindings learnable late in sequence, out-of-distribution bindings acquirable through sequential exposure.
candidates.mechanism_2: Residual dynamics modeling via decoupling static topology from temporal fluctuations. System learns isometric latent representation preserving geometric constraints (static topology), then models temporal evolution via relative displacements anchored to initial structure rather than absolute coordinates. Separates invariant structural relationships from dynamic conformational changes, improving computational efficiency while maintaining physical fidelity.

candidates.title_1: Game-Theoretic and Algorithmic Analyses of Multi-Agent Routing under Crossing Costs
candidates.title_2: On Path-based Marginal Cost of Heterogeneous Traffic Flow for General Networks
candidates.mechanism_1: Crossing cost (product of opposing-direction agent counts) quantifies conflict risk in asynchronous multi-agent routing. Pure Nash equilibria exist when agents minimize individual crossing exposure. Equilibrium emergence dynamics depend on network structure - general case is PLS-complete, but polynomial-time solvable under mild structural conditions.
candidates.mechanism_2: Path marginal cost in heterogeneous traffic decomposes into intra-class effects (within vehicle type) and inter-class effects (cross-type interactions). Conversion factors derived from heterogeneous link dynamics explicitly model competitive relationships between vehicle classes. Non-differentiability emerges when mixed flow approaches system optimum, as flow competition shifts from continuous to threshold-based at equilibrium.

candidates.title_1: Cross-feeding yields high-dimensional chaos and coexistence of species beyond exclusion principle
candidates.title_2: Habitat heterogeneity and dispersal network structure as drivers of metacommunity dynamics
candidates.mechanism_1: Species cross-feed through metabolite leakage and uptake. Competitive uptake of leaked chemicals creates coupled population-chemical dynamics. Network structure determines attractor types: fixed points, limit cycles, low-dimensional chaos, or high-dimensional chaos. High-dimensional chaos enables coexistence beyond competitive exclusion limits through intermittent switching among quasi-stationary states. Chemical dynamics explore high-dimensional space while populations switch intermittently.
candidates.mechanism_2: Effective dispersal kernel encodes both microscopic dynamical parameters and network topology in coarse-grained metacommunity model. Metapopulation capacity generalizes to non-uniform local extinction rates. Stochasticity from finite carrying capacities yields reduced one-dimensional description with universal finite-size scaling laws for extinction times. Homogeneous environments require fine-tuned marginally stable coexistence to avoid monodominance.

candidates.title_1: Indirect Reciprocity with Environmental Feedback
candidates.title_2: Structure-aware imitation dynamics on higher-order networks
candidates.mechanism_1: Individual behaviors shape reputation through social norms while simultaneously affecting collective resource levels. Environmental changes alter payoff structures, creating feedback between strategic behavior and resource dynamics. Reputation-based cooperation interacts with ecological constraints - cooperative behaviors deplete or enhance shared resources, which then reshape the incentives for future cooperation.
candidates.mechanism_2: Higher-order network structure (beyond pairwise) shapes imitation dynamics through group-dependent adoption rates. Information diversity achieved through structured sampling from local neighborhoods. Adoption probability depends on group composition and size, not just neighbor count. Network hypergraph structure determines equilibrium strategy distributions through sampling bias.

candidates.title_1: The impact of heterogeneity on the co-evolution of cooperation and epidemic spreading in complex networks
candidates.title_2: A theory for coexistence and selection of branched actin networks in a shared and finite pool of monomers
candidates.mechanism_1: Cooperation and disease transmission coevolve through network structure. Structural heterogeneity creates leverage points - highly connected hubs adopt protection due to amplified risk, catalyzing cooperation. Cost heterogeneity creates weakest links - low-risk individuals free-ride and act as disease reservoirs, undermining cooperation. Heterogeneity is double-edged: influence asymmetry facilitates cooperation, motivation asymmetry degrades it.
candidates.mechanism_2: Local monomer depletion from network growth creates negative feedback between network density and growth rate. Higher density causes faster monomer consumption and slower growth. Multiple networks sharing finite monomer pool reach steady states through self-regulation. Under strong competition, coexistence transitions to selection.

candidates.title_1: Discrete dynamical systems with scaling and inversion symmetries
candidates.title_2: Coarse-graining and stochastic oscillations in a phenomenological model of cell-size homeostasis
candidates.mechanism_1: System state evolves discretely through iterated function. Scaling symmetry preserves dynamics under magnification/contraction. Near fixed points, small perturbations grow exponentially (positive Lyapunov exponent) causing sensitive dependence. Trajectories confined to fractal attractor with non-integer dimension. Chaotic regime characterized by scaling laws and self-similarity across scales.
candidates.mechanism_2: Cell size feedback operates through size deviations (difference between absolute size and cell-cycle progression). Feedback from size to growth rate and cycle timing creates coupled dynamics. In linear regime, dynamics reduce to stochastically forced harmonic oscillator. Cell-cycle timing and intrinsic fluctuations jointly shape size control strategy. Mechanistic feedback structure may differ from apparent coarse-grained correlations due to noise integration.

candidates.title_1: From Discrete to Continuous Mixed Populations of Conformists, Nonconformists, and Imitators
candidates.title_2: Mathematical Modeling of Common-Pool Resources: A Comprehensive Review of Bioeconomics, Strategic Interaction, and Complex Adaptive Systems
candidates.mechanism_1: Three behavioral types interact: conformists benefit from choosing common strategies, nonconformists profit from rare strategies, and imitators copy highest earners. Population proportions fluctuate in finite populations but equilibrate as population size increases. Strategy proportions undergo perpetual oscillations in small populations, but fluctuation amplitudes approach zero in large populations through stochastic averaging.
candidates.mechanism_2: Paradigm shift from static optimization to dynamic resilience in commons management. Early deterministic bioeconomic models established individual-collective efficiency tension. Ostrom turn integrated institutional monitoring and sanctions into game theory. Evolutionary dynamics and behavioral economics relaxed rationality. Stochastic models capture spatial heterogeneity and noise-induced regime shifts with early warning signals.

candidates.title_1: Technology Adoption and Network Externalities in Financial Systems: A Spatial-Network Approach
candidates.title_2: Strategic Interactions in Science and Technology Networks: Substitutes or Complements?
candidates.mechanism_1: Technology adoption spreads through spatial and network channels. Spatial spillovers and network externalities interact multiplicatively - nearby adoption and connected peer adoption amplify each other. Cumulative adoption pressure accumulates along stochastic paths through spatial-network space. Network position amplifies or dampens spatial effects, creating non-linear adoption dynamics.
candidates.mechanism_2: Productivity in scientific and technological activities increases with Katz-Bonacich centrality capturing within-activity and cross-activity complementarities. Scientific productivity significantly enhances technological output (asymmetric linkage), but technology does not reciprocally boost science. Science-driven innovation model where collaboration structure influences knowledge creation through network position and cross-domain spillovers.

candidates.title_1: Metastability and ripening of multi-component liquid mixtures
candidates.title_2: Distributed delay stabilizes bistable genetic networks
candidates.mechanism_1: Multi-component mixtures undergo phase separation through unstable coexistence. Droplets grow via Ostwald ripening with characteristic scaling (radius ~ t^1/3, number ~ n^-2/3). Glass-like relaxation emerges from disordered interactions among components, creating long-lived metastable states. Different wetting angles characterize metastable configurations. Relaxation delay arises from kinetic barriers between metastable states.
candidates.mechanism_2: Protein production involves delayed multi-step process (transcription, translation, folding, oligomerization). Delay is distributed (noisy) due to stochastic process durations. Increasing delay noise dramatically stabilizes metastable states in bistable circuits. Mean residence times in metastable states increase with delay distribution width. Distributed delay prevents unwanted switching caused by small fluctuations while allowing controlled transitions.

candidates.mechanism_1: Under stress, cells face rapid pathway selection with ATP scarcity. Continuous ATP regeneration rescues sporulation despite 99.7% ATP depletion. GTP accumulates as energy buffer while ATP regenerates preventing complete depletion. Stochastic regulatory transitions couple to continuous metabolic flux. Energy efficiency emerges from interplay between discrete regulatory logic and continuous thermodynamic constraints. System robustness through dynamic energy management enables 16-fold efficiency gain under stress.
candidates.mechanism_2: Controllability-efficiency tradeoff in coupled resource management: independent regulation of multiple coupled resources requires balanced abundances to prevent cross-interference, but balanced states incur higher thermodynamic costs through increased entropy production.

candidates.title_1: Thermalization in classical systems with discrete phase space
candidates.title_2: Noisy nonlocal aggregation model with gradient flow structures
candidates.mechanism_1: Local ergodicity in subsystems, rather than global ergodicity, enables thermalization. Subsystem dynamics appear pseudorandom due to local interactions. Statistical properties of observables emerge from this effective local randomization without requiring the entire system to be ergodic.
candidates.mechanism_2: Stochastic perturbations in nonlocal aggregation systems create gradient-flow structure in Wasserstein space. Noise regulates density and prevents singular concentration through equilibrium states from constrained energy minimization. Stable energy minimizers emerge from interplay between potential-driven interactions and environmental variability.

candidates.title_1: Structure-aware imitation dynamics on higher-order networks

Many macroscopic organizations are excluded a priori even when locally-compatible interactions exist, shifting explanation from generative mechanisms to structural impossibility.

candidates.title_1: Pairwise is Not Enough: Hypergraph Neural Networks for Multi-Agent Pathfinding
candidates.title_2: Crossing the Functional Desert: Cascade-Driven Assembly and Feasibility Transitions in Early Life
candidates.mechanism_1: Hypergraph attention captures group (beyond pairwise) coordination dynamics in multi-agent pathfinding. Standard GNNs limited to pairwise message passing suffer attention dilution in dense environments where group coordination is critical. Attentional mechanisms over directed hypergraphs explicitly model higher-order interactions, mitigating representational bottleneck and enabling complex coordination where pairwise methods fail.
candidates.mechanism_2: Functional organization transitions at critical connectivity: below threshold, cascades die locally creating a functional desert (sparse, transient responses); near percolation threshold, system-spanning cascades emerge enabling discriminative responses. Connectivity-driven transition introduces coherence timescales and weak path-dependence into otherwise memoryless exploration. Network dynamics alone soften combinatorial feasibility barriers without requiring specific biochemistry.

candidates.title_2: Phase Transitions in Unsupervised Feature Selection

candidates.title_2: Understanding the temperature response of biological systems: Part II -- Network-level mechanisms and emergent dynamics
candidates.mechanism_1: Multi-mode coupled non-equilibrium relaxation with cross-mode energy exchange. System tracks multiple energy pools (translational, rotational degrees of freedom) with distinct temperatures evolving through collision-mediated energy transfer. Relaxation dynamics exhibit mode coupling where heat flux interactions between pools affect global equilibration rates, creating thermal conductivity dependence on degree of inter-mode non-equilibrium.

Network coupling creates effective nonlinearities and collective constraints, transforming simple exponential dependencies into complex organism-level thermal responses.

candidates.title_2: OdysseyArena: Benchmarking Large Language Models For Long-Horizon, Active and Inductive Interactions

candidates.mechanism_2: Inductive rule discovery from interaction experience vs deductive execution from explicit rules. Agent must autonomously infer latent transition dynamics through long-horizon active exploration rather than following pre-specified environmental laws. Requires building internal model of state evolution from observed trajectories, enabling strategic foresight and coherent planning over extended interaction sequences.

candidates.title_2: Greedy Routing Reachability Games

Necromass recycling and complementary food sources dampen oscillations by facilitating growth.
candidates.mechanism_2: Temporal niche differentiation through phenotypic plasticity in circadian rhythms enables species coexistence. Coexistence emerges when plastic responses generate sufficient temporal separation in resource use patterns.

candidates.title_1: Habitat heterogeneity and dispersal network structure as drivers of metacommunity dynamics
candidates.title_2: An attention economy model of co-evolution between content quality and audience selectivity
candidates.mechanism_1: Spatial structure and dispersal networks jointly determine species persistence. Heterogeneous habitats support stable coexistence only above a critical heterogeneity threshold. Homogeneous environments allow coexistence only in a fine-tuned marginal state, creating instability. Network topology encodes dispersal effectiveness through an effective kernel.
candidates.mechanism_2: Seed dormancy as bet-hedging strategy in temporally fluctuating environments. Germination fraction trades off current reproduction against future survival through dormant seed bank. Optimal dormancy level depends on environmental variability - higher variance favors increased dormancy. Multi-year averaging through seed bank buffers against temporal unpredictability.

candidates.title_1: Indirect Reciprocity with Environmental Feedback
candidates.title_2: Mathematical Modeling of Common-Pool Resources: A Comprehensive Review of Bioeconomics, Strategic Interaction, and Complex Adaptive Systems
candidates.mechanism_1: Individual behaviors shape reputation through social norms while simultaneously affecting collective resource levels. Environmental changes alter payoff structures, creating feedback between strategic behavior and resource dynamics. Reputation-based cooperation interacts with ecological constraints - cooperative behaviors deplete or enhance shared resources, which then reshape the incentives for future cooperation.
candidates.mechanism_2: Paradigm shift from static optimization to dynamic resilience in commons management. Early deterministic bioeconomic models established individual-collective efficiency tension. Ostrom turn integrated institutional monitoring and sanctions into game theory. Evolutionary dynamics and behavioral economics relaxed rationality. Stochastic models capture spatial heterogeneity and noise-induced regime shifts with early warning signals.

candidates.title_1: Group Selection as a Safeguard Against AI Substitution
candidates.title_2: The Architecture of Illusion: Network Opacity and Strategic Escalation
candidates.mechanism_1: AI use reduces cultural variance in populations. Under individual selection, agents relying heavily on AI (substitutes) outcompete those using AI as complement, despite reducing variance more. Group selection can favor agents that maintain variance through complementary AI use when group boundaries are strong, creating selection-level competition.
candidates.mechanism_2: Network-mediated observation bias creates systematic misperception in strategic reasoning. Agents observe only network-local sample biased by position (algorithmic ranking, homophily), not global population. Locality parameter controls observation bias magnitude, creating distorted beliefs about opponent sophistication that drive strategic escalation beyond what accurate global information would produce.

candidates.title_1: FinEvo: From Isolated Backtests to Ecological Market Games for Multi-Agent Financial Strategy Evolution
candidates.title_2: On the Uncertainty of Large Language Model-Based Multi-Agent Systems

candidates.title_1: Strategic Interactions in Science and Technology Networks: Substitutes or Complements?

Science-driven innovation model where collaboration structure influences knowledge creation through network position and cross-domain spillovers.
candidates.mechanism_2: Expert importance exhibits dual structure: relational importance (routing frequency, interaction centrality) diverges from intrinsic importance (causal influence via gradient attribution). Frequently-routed experts may act as structural hubs with limited functional impact, while sparsely-routed experts can be causally critical. Masking intrinsically-important experts causes disproportionate collapse in interaction topology compared to masking frequent peers, revealing hidden causal dependencies.

candidates.title_1: Chaotic Dynamics in Extremal Black Holes: A Challenge to the Chaos Bound
candidates.title_2: Numerical stationary states for nonlocal Fokker-Planck equations via fixed points of consistency maps
candidates.mechanism_1: Particle motion in extremal configurations exhibits positive Lyapunov exponents indicating sensitivity to initial conditions. Chaos persists even at zero temperature. System parameters (spin, charge) modulate chaos strength - increasing one parameter strengthens chaotic behavior while the other weakens it.
candidates.mechanism_2: Stationary states (both stable and unstable) are computed via fixed-point iteration of a consistency map derived from the PDE and nonlocal interactions. The method is agnostic to dynamical stability—detecting equilibria regardless of whether they attract or repel trajectories. This separates statics (equilibrium existence) from dynamics (stability), enabling discovery of unstable stationary configurations invisible to time-evolution methods.

candidates.title_1: Cross-feeding yields high-dimensional chaos and coexistence of species beyond exclusion principle
candidates.title_2: Optimal Control Strategies for Epidemic Dynamics: Integrating SIR-SI and Lotka--Volterra Models

Network structure determines attractor types: fixed points, limit cycles, low-dimensional chaos, or high-dimensional chaos. High-dimensional chaos enables coexistence beyond competitive exclusion limits through intermittent switching among quasi-stationary states. Chemical dynamics explore high-dimensional space while populations switch intermittently.
candidates.mechanism_2: Coupled multi-timescale dynamics with threshold-based control transition. Fast epidemiological process coupled to slow ecological oscillation, where amplitude of slow cycle determines disease persistence via threshold (ecological reproduction number). Natural control sufficient above threshold; below threshold requires engineered intervention to navigate both timescales simultaneously.

The system exhibits multi-stability and hysteresis - small parameter changes can cause abrupt shifts between cooperation and free-riding equilibria.
candidates.mechanism_2: Agents care about their performance relative to connected peers. Relative performance concerns create strategic interdependencies through network links. Risk-taking behavior adjusts based on peer comparisons. Network topology determines how competitive pressures propagate. This peer comparison mechanism affects equilibrium asset prices through aggregated strategic adjustments.

candidates.title_1: Uncertainty in Island-based Ecosystem Services and Climate Change
candidates.title_2: Optimal Control Strategies for Epidemic Dynamics: Integrating SIR-SI and Lotka--Volterra Models
candidates.mechanism_1: Transmission rate increases with infected density. Recovery rate decreases infection duration. When transmission exceeds recovery (R0>1), epidemic spreads exponentially. Vaccination reduces susceptible population shifting R0 below 1. Spatial heterogeneity creates local pockets where R0 varies.
candidates.mechanism_2: Coupled multi-timescale dynamics with threshold-based control transition. Fast epidemiological process coupled to slow ecological oscillation, where amplitude of slow cycle determines disease persistence via threshold (ecological reproduction number). Natural control sufficient above threshold; below threshold requires engineered intervention to navigate both timescales simultaneously.

candidates.title_1: Unleashing the Potential of Differential Evolution through Individual-Level Strategy Diversity
candidates.title_2: Modeling tumor progression in heterogeneous microenvironments: A cellular automata approach
candidates.mechanism_1: Assigning mutation and crossover strategies independently to each individual at initialization and keeping them fixed creates persistent behavioral heterogeneity. Static individual-level diversity (no adaptation) cultivates search effectiveness especially with large populations. Communication-free construction enables intrinsic concurrency and efficient parallel execution.
candidates.mechanism_2: Environmental state dominates progression dynamics over intrinsic mutation rates in spatially structured systems: supportive environments amplify weak growth signals into invasive spread, while inhibitory environments suppress even high-mutation populations.

candidates.title_1: ROMAN: Reward-Orchestrated Multi-Head Attention Network for Autonomous Driving System Testing
candidates.title_2: Higher-order adaptive behaviors outperform pairwise strategies in mitigating contagion dynamics
candidates.mechanism_1: Reward-orchestrated multi-head attention for high-risk scenario generation. Multiple attention heads each explore different dimension of scenario space (traffic law compliance, environmental complexity, safety risk), with reward function orchestrating attention allocation to prioritize generation of rare critical edge cases that expose system vulnerabilities rather than common benign scenarios.
candidates.mechanism_2: Higher-order information creates heterogeneous risk perception targeting structural hubs and high-participation nodes, preventing contagion exploitation of these critical paths at lower social cost than uniform interventions.

candidates.title_1: Imperfect Turing Patterns: Diffusiophoretic Assembly of Hard Spheres via Reaction-Diffusion Instabilities
candidates.title_2: Understanding the temperature response of biological systems: Part II -- Network-level mechanisms and emergent dynamics
candidates.mechanism_1: Multi-scale pattern formation via coupled reaction-diffusion and particle assembly. Classical Turing mechanism (single length scale from reaction-diffusion balance) coupled to finite-size particle assembly driven by background chemical gradient (diffusiophoresis) plus particle-particle interactions. Introduces additional control parameters (particle size, Péclet number, interaction strength) creating imperfections, grain textures, and multi-scale structures.
candidates.mechanism_2: Individual Arrhenius-like temperature dependence at reaction level transforms into non-Arrhenius scaling, thermal limits, and temperature compensation at network level. Coupled biochemical reactions with temperature-modulated kinetics exhibit emergent system-level temperature response curves that differ from component behaviors. Network coupling creates effective nonlinearities and collective constraints, transforming simple exponential dependencies into complex organism-level thermal responses.

candidates.title_1: Thermodynamic Origin of Degree-Day Scaling in Phase-Change Systems
candidates.title_2: Crossing the Functional Desert: Cascade-Driven Assembly and Feasibility Transitions in Early Life
candidates.mechanism_1: Phase transitions impose topological constraints that mask energetic fluctuations. Introducing a latent temperature (counterfactual unconstrained trajectory) resolves information loss. Energy conservation enforces duality: total latent heat dissipated equals accumulated exceedance of latent temperature above melting point. This duality is mathematically equivalent to Wasserstein-1 distance (optimal transport) between latent and observed trajectories, with phase change emerging as transport that projects continuous energy variability onto constrained thermodynamic boundaries.
candidates.mechanism_2: Functional organization transitions at critical connectivity: below threshold, cascades die locally creating a functional desert (sparse, transient responses); near percolation threshold, system-spanning cascades emerge enabling discriminative responses. Connectivity-driven transition introduces coherence timescales and weak path-dependence into otherwise memoryless exploration. Network dynamics alone soften combinatorial feasibility barriers without requiring specific biochemistry.

candidates.title_1: Coarse-graining and stochastic oscillations in a phenomenological model of cell-size homeostasis
candidates.title_2: Optimal Control Strategies for Epidemic Dynamics: Integrating SIR-SI and Lotka--Volterra Models
candidates.mechanism_1: Cell size feedback operates through size deviations (difference between absolute size and cell-cycle progression). Feedback from size to growth rate and cycle timing creates coupled dynamics. In linear regime, dynamics reduce to stochastically forced harmonic oscillator. Cell-cycle timing and intrinsic fluctuations jointly shape size control strategy. Mechanistic feedback structure may differ from apparent coarse-grained correlations due to noise integration.
candidates.mechanism_2: Coupled multi-timescale dynamics with threshold-based control transition. Fast epidemiological process coupled to slow ecological oscillation, where amplitude of slow cycle determines disease persistence via threshold (ecological reproduction number). Natural control sufficient above threshold; below threshold requires engineered intervention to navigate both timescales simultaneously.

candidates.title_1: Normative Equivalence in Human-AI Cooperation: Behaviour, Not Identity, Drives Cooperation in Mixed-Agent Groups
candidates.title_2: Low-Dimensional Interaction Spaces Impose Geometric Constraints On Collective Organization
candidates.mechanism_1: Reciprocal group dynamics and behavioral inertia drive cooperation levels in groups. Cooperation depends on observed group behavior patterns rather than the identity of participants. These normative mechanisms operate identically regardless of agent type, creating stable cooperation patterns through behavioral feedback.
candidates.mechanism_2: When effective interactions among system components compress into low-dimensional interaction space, global organization is governed by geometric constraints rather than detailed dynamics. Low interaction dimensionality imposes upper bounds on number, separability, and robustness of collective organizations. Many macroscopic organizations are excluded a priori even when locally-compatible interactions exist, shifting explanation from generative mechanisms to structural impossibility.

candidates.title_1: Intelligent Control of Transportation Flow in Physarum Networks
candidates.title_2: Stability and robustness of a generalized pump-leak model for epithelial cell and lumen volume regulation
candidates.mechanism_1: Physarum network morphology responds to environmental stimuli by expanding or retracting tubes. Cytoplasmic flow bidirectionally transports nutrients through the network. Flow patterns optimize based on nutrient source locations. Network adapts topology through tube reinforcement when flow is high and tube degradation when flow is low. This creates an intelligent search for optimal transport paths through flow-structure feedback.
candidates.mechanism_2: Epithelial cells regulate volume through coordinated ion pumps, channels, and paracellular pathways. Pumps actively transport ions creating concentration gradients. Osmotic pressure drives water flow following ion movement. Cell-lumen interaction creates coupled volume dynamics. Pump rates, leak permeabilities, and osmotic coupling determine stability. Feedback between cell volume and pump activity maintains homeostasis.

candidates.title_1: Intermittent precipitation and spatial Allee effects drive irregular vegetation patterns in semiarid ecosystems
candidates.title_2: Distinguishable spreading dynamics in microbial communities
candidates.mechanism_1: Plants facilitate neighboring growth through local resource modification. Facilitation competes with resource competition. When precipitation is intermittent, facilitation-competition balance creates spatial vegetation patterns. Below threshold density, vegetation collapses due to weakened facilitation (spatial Allee effect).
candidates.mechanism_2: Proliferation limitations determine spreading dynamics. Growth arrest causes superlinear spreading at reduced rate. Pressure-limited growth produces linear constant-speed spreading. Nutrient-limited growth exhibits phase transition: superlinear when nutrient supply is high, sublinear when depleted. Nutrient supply and conversion efficiency determine phase boundary. Spreading rate distinguishes dominant limitation type.

candidates.title_1: Growth Models Under Uniform Catastrophes
candidates.title_2: Optimal Control Strategies for Epidemic Dynamics: Integrating SIR-SI and Lotka--Volterra Models
candidates.mechanism_1: Catastrophic events trigger population dispersal strategies. Dispersion affects survival probability and extinction time. Spatial constraints modulate the effectiveness of dispersal - unconstrained dispersion improves survival while spatial limits reduce the benefit, creating a trade-off between mobility and stability.
candidates.mechanism_2: Coupled multi-timescale dynamics with threshold-based control transition. Fast epidemiological process coupled to slow ecological oscillation, where amplitude of slow cycle determines disease persistence via threshold (ecological reproduction number). Natural control sufficient above threshold; below threshold requires engineered intervention to navigate both timescales simultaneously.

candidates.title_1: A phenomenological description of critical slowing down at period-doubling bifurcations
candidates.title_2: The near-continuum mechanism for extended Boltzmann theory: the non-equilibrium relaxation
candidates.mechanism_1: As a system approaches a bifurcation point, convergence to steady state slows dramatically. Near criticality, relaxation time diverges according to universal scaling laws. The system exhibits characteristic critical exponents that govern short-time behavior, asymptotic decay, and crossover between regimes.
candidates.mechanism_2: Multi-mode coupled non-equilibrium relaxation with cross-mode energy exchange. System tracks multiple energy pools (translational, rotational degrees of freedom) with distinct temperatures evolving through collision-mediated energy transfer. Relaxation dynamics exhibit mode coupling where heat flux interactions between pools affect global equilibration rates, creating thermal conductivity dependence on degree of inter-mode non-equilibrium.

candidates.title_1: FinEvo: From Isolated Backtests to Ecological Market Games for Multi-Agent Financial Strategy Evolution
candidates.title_2: AEGPO: Adaptive Entropy-Guided Policy Optimization for Diffusion Models
candidates.mechanism_1: Strategy distributions evolve through selection (performance-based survival), innovation (mutation), and environmental perturbation (external shocks). Individual agents adapt using local signals while population composition shifts based on relative fitness. Two-layer adaptation - individual learning plus population-level evolution - determines whether strategies persist, collapse, or form coalitions.
candidates.mechanism_2: Dual-signal adaptive resource allocation using entropy as proxy for learning value. Global level: relative entropy change identifies high-value samples for prioritized exploration. Local level: absolute entropy peaks identify critical moments within each trajectory. Concentrates computation where information gain is highest rather than uniform distribution.

candidates.title_1: A phenomenological description of critical slowing down at period-doubling bifurcations

The system exhibits characteristic critical exponents that govern short-time behavior, asymptotic decay, and crossover between regimes.

Epiplexity (structural information encoding) and empowerment (control capacity) provide recognition vs. control axes for physical intelligence. candidates.title_1: Impact of seed node position on network robustness under localized attacks
candidates.title_2: Crossing the Functional Desert: Cascade-Driven Assembly and Feasibility Transitions in Early Life
candidates.mechanism_1: Localized damage initiates at a seed node and propagates to neighbors. The structural position of the seed node (local connectivity and topology) amplifies or dampens damage progression. Cumulative link severing during attack progression depends critically on seed node characteristics rather than average network properties.
candidates.mechanism_2: Functional organization transitions at critical connectivity: below threshold, cascades die locally creating a functional desert (sparse, transient responses); near percolation threshold, system-spanning cascades emerge enabling discriminative responses. Connectivity-driven transition introduces coherence timescales and weak path-dependence into otherwise memoryless exploration. Network dynamics alone soften combinatorial feasibility barriers without requiring specific biochemistry.

candidates.title_1: All-Atom GPCR-Ligand Simulation via Residual Isometric Latent Flow
candidates.title_2: Decaying Sensitivity of the Zero Solution for a Class of Nonlinear Optimal Control Problems
candidates.mechanism_1: Residual dynamics modeling via decoupling static topology from temporal fluctuations. System learns isometric latent representation preserving geometric constraints (static topology), then models temporal evolution via relative displacements anchored to initial structure rather than absolute coordinates. Separates invariant structural relationships from dynamic conformational changes, improving computational efficiency while maintaining physical fidelity.
candidates.mechanism_2: Localized perturbations in graph-structured systems induce optimal trajectories that decay exponentially with graph distance from perturbation source. Spatial decay arises from interaction topology: influences propagate through network edges but attenuate geometrically with path length. Graph distance acts as effective spatial dimension governing perturbation propagation, with topology imposing decay rate independently of detailed dynamics.

candidates.title_1: FinEvo: From Isolated Backtests to Ecological Market Games for Multi-Agent Financial Strategy Evolution
candidates.title_2: Online Fine-Tuning of Pretrained Controllers for Autonomous Driving via Real-Time Recurrent RL
