candidates.mechanism_2: Dual-scope representation learning with contrastive regularization under distribution shift. System captures both local pairwise regulatory logic and global cross-context expression patterns via dual-head architecture. Contrastive learning enforces structural constraints in representation space, providing robustness against noise, sparsity, and cross-domain distributional shifts beyond what supervised signal alone provides.

candidates.title_1: Intermittent precipitation and spatial Allee effects drive irregular vegetation patterns in semiarid ecosystems
candidates.title_2: Controlling extreme events in neuronal networks: A single driving signal approach
candidates.mechanism_1: Intermittent resource pulses interact with positive density dependence (Allee effects) to generate irregular spatial clusters. During favorable pulses, local facilitation enables patch expansion; during scarcity, neighborhood density determines survival. Resilience emerges from spatial covariance and local density rather than total biomass.
candidates.mechanism_2: Single driving signal targeting one network node suppresses extreme events network-wide through dominance mechanism. Suppression occurs via frequency decoupling - driven neuron breaks from collective proto-event frequency dynamics, disrupting synchronized extreme event generation. Larger driven subpopulation enables earlier control onset, showing scaling advantage.

candidates.title_1: Discrete dynamical systems with scaling and inversion symmetries
candidates.title_2: Multiple timescales in collective motion: daily and intraday upstream fish migration focusing on Feller condition
candidates.mechanism_1: System state evolves discretely through iterated function. Scaling symmetry preserves dynamics under magnification/contraction. Near fixed points, small perturbations grow exponentially (positive Lyapunov exponent) causing sensitive dependence. Trajectories confined to fractal attractor with non-integer dimension. Chaotic regime characterized by scaling laws and self-similarity across scales.
candidates.mechanism_2: The ratio between diffusion and drift (Feller condition) determines qualitative migration properties. High diffusion relative to drift creates randomized, intermittent movement patterns. Low ratio produces more deterministic, continuous movement. This ratio acts as a control parameter governing timescale-dependent behavioral transitions.

candidates.title_1: Piecewise Deterministic Markov Processes for Bayesian Inference of PDE Coefficients
candidates.title_2: Landscape-aware Automated Algorithm Design: An Efficient Framework for Real-world Optimization
candidates.mechanism_1: Surrogate-assisted proposal generation with dynamic correction bounds enables efficient exploration when exact evaluations are expensive: surrogate provides cheap proposals, dynamic offset enforcement maintains correctness.
candidates.mechanism_2: Landscape-similarity proxies decouple algorithm discovery from expensive target evaluation: generating cheap proxy problems matching target's landscape characteristics enables extensive algorithm search before costly validation.

candidates.title_1: Analytical and numerical study of a parametrically excited 2DOF oscillator with nonlinear restoring magnetic force and rotating rectangular rod
candidates.title_2: Coarse-graining and stochastic oscillations in a phenomenological model of cell-size homeostasis
candidates.mechanism_1: Time-periodic stiffness variation induces parametric excitation in coupled components. Nonlinear restoring forces and friction interact to produce a spectrum of dynamic responses including periodic, quasi-periodic, and chaotic behaviors. System parameters (stiffness degree, mass symmetry, friction) determine stability boundaries and response amplitude.
candidates.mechanism_2: Cell size feedback operates through size deviations (difference between absolute size and cell-cycle progression). Feedback from size to growth rate and cycle timing creates coupled dynamics. In linear regime, dynamics reduce to stochastically forced harmonic oscillator. Cell-cycle timing and intrinsic fluctuations jointly shape size control strategy. Mechanistic feedback structure may differ from apparent coarse-grained correlations due to noise integration.

candidates.title_1: Structure-aware imitation dynamics on higher-order networks
candidates.title_2: Decaying Sensitivity of the Zero Solution for a Class of Nonlinear Optimal Control Problems
candidates.mechanism_1: Higher-order network structure (beyond pairwise) shapes imitation dynamics through group-dependent adoption rates. Information diversity achieved through structured sampling from local neighborhoods. Adoption probability depends on group composition and size, not just neighbor count. Network hypergraph structure determines equilibrium strategy distributions through sampling bias.
candidates.mechanism_2: Localized perturbations in graph-structured systems induce optimal trajectories that decay exponentially with graph distance from perturbation source. Spatial decay arises from interaction topology: influences propagate through network edges but attenuate geometrically with path length. Graph distance acts as effective spatial dimension governing perturbation propagation, with topology imposing decay rate independently of detailed dynamics.

candidates.title_1: A Minimal Task Reveals Emergent Path Integration and Object-Location Binding in a Predictive Sequence Model
candidates.title_2: Neural Ordinary Differential Equations for Simulating Metabolic Pathway Dynamics from Time-Series Multiomics Data
candidates.mechanism_1: Action-conditioned sequential prediction enables path integration and dynamic object-location binding for world modeling. Prediction accuracy improves across sequence through in-context learning. Structured representations with flexible binding emerge to support prediction - new bindings learnable late in sequence, out-of-distribution bindings acquirable through sequential exposure.
candidates.mechanism_2: Proteome-metabolome dynamics are modeled as continuous interplay via Neural ODEs. Rather than requiring pre-specified mechanistic knowledge, NODEs infer latent interaction structure directly from time-series multiomics data. Learned continuous dynamics enable simulation of temporal trajectories and anticipation of intervention effects, capturing complex feedback between protein expression and metabolite concentrations without manually encoding pathway topology.

candidates.title_1: Structure-aware imitation dynamics on higher-order networks
candidates.title_2: Learning to Share: Selective Memory for Efficient Parallel Agentic Systems
candidates.mechanism_1: Higher-order network structure (beyond pairwise) shapes imitation dynamics through group-dependent adoption rates. Information diversity achieved through structured sampling from local neighborhoods. Adoption probability depends on group composition and size, not just neighbor count. Network hypergraph structure determines equilibrium strategy distributions through sampling bias.
candidates.mechanism_2: Learned selective information sharing across parallel exploration processes. Multiple independent teams explore different solution trajectories with learned controller deciding which intermediate results to place in globally-accessible shared memory. Balances exploration diversity (parallel independence) against computational efficiency (reuse of overlapping sub-solutions), using stepwise credit assignment to identify globally useful information.

candidates.title_1: The impact of heterogeneity on the co-evolution of cooperation and epidemic spreading in complex networks
candidates.title_2: Impact of behavioral heterogeneity on epidemic outcome and its mapping into effective network topologies
candidates.mechanism_1: Cooperation and disease transmission coevolve through network structure. Structural heterogeneity creates leverage points - highly connected hubs adopt protection due to amplified risk, catalyzing cooperation. Cost heterogeneity creates weakest links - low-risk individuals free-ride and act as disease reservoirs, undermining cooperation. Heterogeneity is double-edged: influence asymmetry facilitates cooperation, motivation asymmetry degrades it.
candidates.mechanism_2: Behavioral heterogeneity with homophily creates resurgence dynamics near critical thresholds: diverse risk responses combined with preferential interaction among similar types produces initial decline followed by secondary surge as low-risk subpopulation becomes infected.

candidates.title_1: Technology Adoption and Network Externalities in Financial Systems: A Spatial-Network Approach
candidates.title_2: Disentangling Causal Importance from Emergent Structure in Multi-Expert Orchestration
candidates.mechanism_1: Technology adoption spreads through spatial and network channels. Spatial spillovers and network externalities interact multiplicatively - nearby adoption and connected peer adoption amplify each other. Cumulative adoption pressure accumulates along stochastic paths through spatial-network space. Network position amplifies or dampens spatial effects, creating non-linear adoption dynamics.
candidates.mechanism_2: Expert importance exhibits dual structure: relational importance (routing frequency, interaction centrality) diverges from intrinsic importance (causal influence via gradient attribution). Frequently-routed experts may act as structural hubs with limited functional impact, while sparsely-routed experts can be causally critical. Masking intrinsically-important experts causes disproportionate collapse in interaction topology compared to masking frequent peers, revealing hidden causal dependencies.

candidates.title_1: FinEvo: From Isolated Backtests to Ecological Market Games for Multi-Agent Financial Strategy Evolution
candidates.title_2: Markov Decision Processes of the Third Kind: Learning Distributions by Policy Gradient Descent
candidates.mechanism_1: Strategy distributions evolve through selection (performance-based survival), innovation (mutation), and environmental perturbation (external shocks). Individual agents adapt using local signals while population composition shifts based on relative fitness. Two-layer adaptation - individual learning plus population-level evolution - determines whether strategies persist, collapse, or form coalitions.
candidates.mechanism_2: Distributional MDPs steer cumulative reward distribution toward target law rather than optimizing expected value. Randomized Markov policies on augmented state space with characteristic-function loss enable distribution matching. Policy gradient converges to stationary points. Non-uniqueness phenomena emerge - multiple distinct policies can achieve same target distribution.

candidates.title_1: A theory for coexistence and selection of branched actin networks in a shared and finite pool of monomers
candidates.title_2: Controlling extreme events in neuronal networks: A single driving signal approach
candidates.mechanism_1: Multiple branched actin networks compete for shared monomer pool. Network growth locally depletes monomers creating negative feedback between network density and growth rate. Local depletion couples network growth rates through shared resource. Under weak competition, networks coexist at steady state. Under strong competition, selection replaces coexistence - fastest-growing network excludes others. Competition strength determined by monomer availability and consumption rates.

candidates.title_1: Effect of higher-order interactions on noisy majority-rule dynamics with random group sizes
candidates.title_2: Mathematical Modeling of Common-Pool Resources: A Comprehensive Review of Bioeconomics, Strategic Interaction, and Complex Adaptive Systems
candidates.mechanism_1: Variable group sizes in majority-rule dynamics create heterogeneous influence through effective majority leverage. Rare large-group events can realign substantial population fractions. Critical threshold for independence depends on group-size distribution - heavy-tailed distributions enhance robustness to disorder through occasional macroscopic coordination events.
candidates.mechanism_2: Paradigm shift from static optimization to dynamic resilience in commons management. Early deterministic bioeconomic models established individual-collective efficiency tension. Ostrom turn integrated institutional monitoring and sanctions into game theory. Evolutionary dynamics and behavioral economics relaxed rationality. Stochastic models capture spatial heterogeneity and noise-induced regime shifts with early warning signals.

candidates.title_1: Collaboration for the Bioeconomy -- Evidence from Innovation Output in Sweden, 1970-2021
candidates.title_2: Structure-aware imitation dynamics on higher-order networks
candidates.mechanism_1: Firms collaborate forming innovation network. Central firms access diverse knowledge from multiple partners enhancing innovation output. Peripheral firms limited by fewer connections. Network structure (centrality) determines innovation capacity. Successful innovators attract more partners (preferential attachment) reinforcing centrality advantage.
candidates.mechanism_2: Higher-order network structure (beyond pairwise) shapes imitation dynamics through group-dependent adoption rates. Information diversity achieved through structured sampling from local neighborhoods. Adoption probability depends on group composition and size, not just neighbor count. Network hypergraph structure determines equilibrium strategy distributions through sampling bias.

candidates.title_1: Cross-feeding yields high-dimensional chaos and coexistence of species beyond exclusion principle
candidates.title_2: GenAI-Net: A Generative AI Framework for Automated Biomolecular Network Design
candidates.mechanism_1: Species cross-feed through metabolite leakage and uptake. Competitive uptake of leaked chemicals creates coupled population-chemical dynamics. Network structure determines attractor types: fixed points, limit cycles, low-dimensional chaos, or high-dimensional chaos. High-dimensional chaos enables coexistence beyond competitive exclusion limits through intermittent switching among quasi-stationary states. Chemical dynamics explore high-dimensional space while populations switch intermittently.
candidates.mechanism_2: Biomolecular network design reverses the typical simulation workflow: instead of checking proposed networks, an agent proposes reactions guided by behavioral specification. Coupling generative proposal with simulation-based evaluation (user-specified objective) produces topologically diverse solutions. The generative component explores reaction space, while simulation evaluates functional fit, enabling automated discovery of networks implementing desired dynamics from specifications.

candidates.title_1: Division of labor enables efficient collective decision-making under uncertainty
candidates.title_2: Entanglement improves coordination in distributed systems
candidates.mechanism_1: Division of labor emerges from heterogeneous response thresholds combined with task-dependent positive feedback. Individuals with low thresholds specialize in corresponding tasks as they activate more frequently and self-reinforce. Threshold distribution determines whether population exhibits generalism or specialized subpopulations. Decentralized coordination through threshold heterogeneity without central control.
candidates.mechanism_2: Non-local quantum correlations enable superior coordination in distributed systems with convex reward functions: instantaneous shared randomness from entanglement avoids communication latency costs when longer uninterrupted processing yields superlinear rewards.

candidates.title_1: Indirect Reciprocity with Environmental Feedback
candidates.title_2: The Architecture of Illusion: Network Opacity and Strategic Escalation
candidates.mechanism_1: Individual behaviors shape reputation through social norms while simultaneously affecting collective resource levels. Environmental changes alter payoff structures, creating feedback between strategic behavior and resource dynamics. Reputation-based cooperation interacts with ecological constraints - cooperative behaviors deplete or enhance shared resources, which then reshape the incentives for future cooperation.
candidates.mechanism_2: Network-mediated observation bias creates systematic misperception in strategic reasoning. Agents observe only network-local sample biased by position (algorithmic ranking, homophily), not global population. Locality parameter controls observation bias magnitude, creating distorted beliefs about opponent sophistication that drive strategic escalation beyond what accurate global information would produce.

candidates.title_1: Optimal Control Strategies for Epidemic Dynamics: Integrating SIR-SI and Lotka--Volterra Models
candidates.title_2: Minimal-Action Discrete Schrödinger Bridge Matching for Peptide Sequence Design
candidates.mechanism_1: Coupled multi-timescale dynamics with threshold-based control transition. Fast epidemiological process coupled to slow ecological oscillation, where amplitude of slow cycle determines disease persistence via threshold (ecological reproduction number). Natural control sufficient above threshold; below threshold requires engineered intervention to navigate both timescales simultaneously.
candidates.mechanism_2: Controlled transport relative to informed reference process yields low-action paths through high-likelihood regions: defining generation as deviation from biologically-informed baseline keeps intermediate states plausible throughout trajectory.

candidates.title_1: Coarse-graining and stochastic oscillations in a phenomenological model of cell-size homeostasis

candidates.title_2: A theory for coexistence and selection of branched actin networks in a shared and finite pool of monomers

This peer comparison mechanism affects equilibrium asset prices through aggregated strategic adjustments.

Entropy production and predictive information depend strongly on heterogeneity but weakly on asymmetry. Near criticality, small heterogeneity changes cause large dynamical shifts.
candidates.mechanism_2: Controlled transport relative to informed reference process yields low-action paths through high-likelihood regions: defining generation as deviation from biologically-informed baseline keeps intermediate states plausible throughout trajectory.

candidates.title_2: Optimal Control Strategies for Epidemic Dynamics: Integrating SIR-SI and Lotka--Volterra Models

Trade-off between extrinsic and intrinsic control.

Population proportions fluctuate in finite populations but equilibrate as population size increases. Strategy proportions undergo perpetual oscillations in small populations, but fluctuation amplitudes approach zero in large populations through stochastic averaging.
candidates.mechanism_2: Assigning mutation and crossover strategies independently to each individual at initialization and keeping them fixed creates persistent behavioral heterogeneity. Static individual-level diversity (no adaptation) cultivates search effectiveness especially with large populations. Communication-free construction enables intrinsic concurrency and efficient parallel execution.

candidates.title_2: A brief review of evolutionary game dynamics in the reinforcement learning paradigm
candidates.mechanism_1: AI use reduces cultural variance in populations. Group selection can favor agents that maintain variance through complementary AI use when group boundaries are strong, creating selection-level competition.

Individuals learn from environmental feedback and adapt based on personal experience. This resolves discrepancies between theoretical predictions and behavioral experiments in cooperation, trust, and fairness.

candidates.title_2: Crossing the Functional Desert: Cascade-Driven Assembly and Feasibility Transitions in Early Life

The system exhibits characteristic critical exponents that govern short-time behavior, asymptotic decay, and crossover between regimes.
candidates.mechanism_2: Functional organization transitions at critical connectivity: below threshold, cascades die locally creating a functional desert (sparse, transient responses); near percolation threshold, system-spanning cascades emerge enabling discriminative responses. Connectivity-driven transition introduces coherence timescales and weak path-dependence into otherwise memoryless exploration. Network dynamics alone soften combinatorial feasibility barriers without requiring specific biochemistry.

candidates.title_2: Neural Ordinary Differential Equations for Simulating Metabolic Pathway Dynamics from Time-Series Multiomics Data

candidates.title_1: Emergence of Superintelligence from Collective Near-Critical Dynamics in Reentrant Neural Fields
candidates.title_2: Understanding the temperature response of biological systems: Part II -- Network-level mechanisms and emergent dynamics
candidates.mechanism_1: Qualitative phase transition via spectral condensation at criticality. Progressive reentrant coupling drives system toward infrared critical regime where extensive band of slow collective modes emerges (spectral condensation), reorganizing dynamics qualitatively. Creates emergent capabilities absent at subcritical regime - transition in kind not degree, regardless of system scale.
candidates.mechanism_2: Individual Arrhenius-like temperature dependence at reaction level transforms into non-Arrhenius scaling, thermal limits, and temperature compensation at network level. Coupled biochemical reactions with temperature-modulated kinetics exhibit emergent system-level temperature response curves that differ from component behaviors. Network coupling creates effective nonlinearities and collective constraints, transforming simple exponential dependencies into complex organism-level thermal responses.

candidates.title_1: Cell size control in bacteria is modulated through extrinsic noise, single-cell- and population-growth
candidates.title_2: Distinguishable spreading dynamics in microbial communities
candidates.mechanism_1: Cell size fluctuates due to noisy growth rates and size-dependent division noise. Size homeostasis mechanisms compensate for fluctuations through size control strategies. Population dynamics alter size distributions compared to single lineages - exponential population growth changes the effective size control measured in constant-volume experiments. Extrinsic growth noise and population structure jointly determine observed size distributions.
candidates.mechanism_2: Proliferation limitations determine spreading dynamics. Growth arrest causes superlinear spreading at reduced rate. Pressure-limited growth produces linear constant-speed spreading. Nutrient-limited growth exhibits phase transition: superlinear when nutrient supply is high, sublinear when depleted. Nutrient supply and conversion efficiency determine phase boundary. Spreading rate distinguishes dominant limitation type.

candidates.title_1: Impact of behavioral heterogeneity on epidemic outcome and its mapping into effective network topologies
candidates.title_2: Full-Covariance Chemical Langevin Predator--Prey Diffusion with Absorbing Boundaries
candidates.mechanism_1: Behavioral heterogeneity with homophily creates resurgence dynamics near critical thresholds: diverse risk responses combined with preferential interaction among similar types produces initial decline followed by secondary surge as low-risk subpopulation becomes infected.
candidates.mechanism_2: Predation creates event-level coupling through biomass conversion: predation-conversion increment (-1,+1) induces strictly negative cross-covariance between prey and predator populations. This mechanistic coupling cannot be captured by diagonal (independent) noise. The coupled dynamics arise from the irreducible stochastic structure of predation events, where prey loss simultaneously causes predator gain, creating intrinsic negative correlation in population fluctuations.

candidates.title_1: Estimating measures of information processing during cognitive tasks using functional magnetic resonance imaging
candidates.title_2: Emulating Aggregate Human Choice Behavior and Biases with GPT Conversational Agents
candidates.mechanism_1: Active information storage (within-region retention), transfer entropy (directed flow), and net synergy (redundancy vs. synergy) quantify information processing. Cross mutual information combines resting-state and task data to address limited samples. AIS increases with cognitive load in fronto-parietal regions; TE reveals enhanced directed flows; net synergy shows global redundancy shift.
candidates.mechanism_2: Cognitive biases shape decision-making through interaction with contextual factors. When cognitive load increases (complex dialogue), pre-existing biases amplify through reduced deliberative capacity. The bias magnitude is context-dependent: simple interactions suppress bias expression, while complex interactions magnify it by consuming cognitive resources that would otherwise moderate biased responses.

candidates.title_1: Controlling extreme events in neuronal networks: A single driving signal approach
candidates.title_2: Emergence and co-existence of periodic and unstructured motion in future-avoiding random walks
candidates.mechanism_1: Single driving signal targeting one network node suppresses extreme events network-wide through dominance mechanism. Suppression occurs via frequency decoupling - driven neuron breaks from collective proto-event frequency dynamics, disrupting synchronized extreme event generation. Larger driven subpopulation enables earlier control onset, showing scaling advantage.
candidates.mechanism_2: Self-amplifying coupling to periodic components of stochastic forcing drives phase transition from unstructured to structured behavior: weak periodic signals in noise become amplified through positive feedback, spontaneously synchronizing system components.

candidates.title_1: Noisy nonlocal aggregation model with gradient flow structures
candidates.title_2: A generalized work theorem for stopped stochastic chemical reaction networks
candidates.mechanism_1: Stochastic perturbations in nonlocal aggregation systems create gradient-flow structure in Wasserstein space. Noise regulates density and prevents singular concentration through equilibrium states from constrained energy minimization. Stable energy minimizers emerge from interplay between potential-driven interactions and environmental variability.
candidates.mechanism_2: Chemical reaction networks exhibit martingale structure in generalized entropy without requiring detailed balance. Martingale properties emerge directly from reaction propensity structure: the jump process compensated with appropriate drift becomes a zero-mean stochastic process. This enables work theorems for arbitrary stopping times and singular initial conditions, generalizing thermodynamic relations beyond equilibrium systems.

candidates.title_1: Optimal Control Strategies for Epidemic Dynamics: Integrating SIR-SI and Lotka--Volterra Models
candidates.title_2: Crossing the Functional Desert: Cascade-Driven Assembly and Feasibility Transitions in Early Life
candidates.mechanism_1: Coupled multi-timescale dynamics with threshold-based control transition. Fast epidemiological process coupled to slow ecological oscillation, where amplitude of slow cycle determines disease persistence via threshold (ecological reproduction number). Natural control sufficient above threshold; below threshold requires engineered intervention to navigate both timescales simultaneously.
candidates.mechanism_2: Functional organization transitions at critical connectivity: below threshold, cascades die locally creating a functional desert (sparse, transient responses); near percolation threshold, system-spanning cascades emerge enabling discriminative responses. Connectivity-driven transition introduces coherence timescales and weak path-dependence into otherwise memoryless exploration. Network dynamics alone soften combinatorial feasibility barriers without requiring specific biochemistry.

candidates.title_1: Group Selection as a Safeguard Against AI Substitution
candidates.title_2: From Discrete to Continuous Mixed Populations of Conformists, Nonconformists, and Imitators
candidates.mechanism_1: AI use reduces cultural variance in populations. Under individual selection, agents relying heavily on AI (substitutes) outcompete those using AI as complement, despite reducing variance more. Group selection can favor agents that maintain variance through complementary AI use when group boundaries are strong, creating selection-level competition.
candidates.mechanism_2: Three behavioral types interact: conformists benefit from choosing common strategies, nonconformists profit from rare strategies, and imitators copy highest earners. Population proportions fluctuate in finite populations but equilibrate as population size increases. Strategy proportions undergo perpetual oscillations in small populations, but fluctuation amplitudes approach zero in large populations through stochastic averaging.

candidates.title_1: DreamDojo: A Generalist Robot World Model from Large-Scale Human Videos
candidates.title_2: All-Atom GPCR-Ligand Simulation via Residual Isometric Latent Flow
candidates.mechanism_1: Continuous latent actions serve as unified proxy actions, enabling interaction knowledge transfer from unlabeled human videos to robot control. World model learns diverse interactions from 44k hours of egocentric video. Post-training on small-scale robot data yields physics understanding and precise action controllability. Generative modeling enables teleoperation, policy evaluation, and planning.
candidates.mechanism_2: Residual dynamics modeling via decoupling static topology from temporal fluctuations. System learns isometric latent representation preserving geometric constraints (static topology), then models temporal evolution via relative displacements anchored to initial structure rather than absolute coordinates. Separates invariant structural relationships from dynamic conformational changes, improving computational efficiency while maintaining physical fidelity.

candidates.title_1: Group Selection as a Safeguard Against AI Substitution
candidates.title_2: Unleashing the Potential of Differential Evolution through Individual-Level Strategy Diversity
candidates.mechanism_1: AI use reduces cultural variance in populations. Under individual selection, agents relying heavily on AI (substitutes) outcompete those using AI as complement, despite reducing variance more. Group selection can favor agents that maintain variance through complementary AI use when group boundaries are strong, creating selection-level competition.
candidates.mechanism_2: Assigning mutation and crossover strategies independently to each individual at initialization and keeping them fixed creates persistent behavioral heterogeneity. Static individual-level diversity (no adaptation) cultivates search effectiveness especially with large populations. Communication-free construction enables intrinsic concurrency and efficient parallel execution.

candidates.title_1: Landscape-aware Automated Algorithm Design: An Efficient Framework for Real-world Optimization
candidates.title_2: Fully Automated Adaptive Parameter Selection for 3-D High-order Nyström Boundary Integral Equation Methods
candidates.mechanism_1: Landscape-similarity proxies decouple algorithm discovery from expensive target evaluation: generating cheap proxy problems matching target's landscape characteristics enables extensive algorithm search before costly validation.
candidates.mechanism_2: Unified adaptive schemes eliminate manual parameter tuning while maintaining accuracy across diverse problem instances: automatic error-driven refinement of resolution and interaction distances adapts to local geometric complexity.

candidates.title_1: Indirect Reciprocity with Environmental Feedback
candidates.title_2: Social Catalysts, Not Moral Agents: The Illusion of Alignment in LLM Societies
candidates.mechanism_1: Individual behaviors shape reputation through social norms while simultaneously affecting collective resource levels. Environmental changes alter payoff structures, creating feedback between strategic behavior and resource dynamics. Reputation-based cooperation interacts with ecological constraints - cooperative behaviors deplete or enhance shared resources, which then reshape the incentives for future cooperation.
candidates.mechanism_2: External behavioral anchors induce strategic compliance and cognitive offloading without genuine norm internalization: agents mimic anchor behavior locally to reduce cognitive load, but revert to self-interested behavior when anchors absent or unobservable.

candidates.title_1: Strategic Interactions in Science and Technology Networks: Substitutes or Complements?
candidates.title_2: Structure-aware imitation dynamics on higher-order networks
candidates.mechanism_1: An agent's position in a collaboration network determines their productivity. Higher network centrality increases output through strategic complementarities with connected agents. Activity in one domain (scientific) enhances productivity in another domain (technological), but this effect is asymmetric - the reverse direction shows no detectable influence.
candidates.mechanism_2: Higher-order network structure (beyond pairwise) shapes imitation dynamics through group-dependent adoption rates. Information diversity achieved through structured sampling from local neighborhoods. Adoption probability depends on group composition and size, not just neighbor count. Network hypergraph structure determines equilibrium strategy distributions through sampling bias.

candidates.title_1: Impulsive Release Strategies for Wolbachia-Infected Mosquitoes under Temperature-Induced Infection Loss
candidates.title_2: Emergence and co-existence of periodic and unstructured motion in future-avoiding random walks
candidates.mechanism_1: Impulsive periodic intervention under environmental stress. System alternates between autonomous dynamics and discrete intervention events (periodic releases), with environmental perturbations (temperature stress) potentially reversing intervention effects. Success threshold depends on balancing intervention frequency, stress magnitude, and fitness costs to maintain desired state despite continuous environmental pressure.
candidates.mechanism_2: Self-amplifying coupling to periodic components of stochastic forcing drives phase transition from unstructured to structured behavior: weak periodic signals in noise become amplified through positive feedback, spontaneously synchronizing system components.

candidates.title_1: A phenomenological description of critical slowing down at period-doubling bifurcations
candidates.title_2: A theory for coexistence and selection of branched actin networks in a shared and finite pool of monomers
candidates.mechanism_1: As a system approaches a bifurcation point, convergence to steady state slows dramatically. Near criticality, relaxation time diverges according to universal scaling laws. The system exhibits characteristic critical exponents that govern short-time behavior, asymptotic decay, and crossover between regimes.
candidates.mechanism_2: Local monomer depletion from network growth creates negative feedback between network density and growth rate. Higher density causes faster monomer consumption and slower growth. Multiple networks sharing finite monomer pool reach steady states through self-regulation. Under strong competition, coexistence transitions to selection.

candidates.title_1: The impact of heterogeneity on the co-evolution of cooperation and epidemic spreading in complex networks
candidates.title_2: Low-Dimensional Interaction Spaces Impose Geometric Constraints On Collective Organization
candidates.mechanism_1: Cooperation and disease transmission coevolve through network structure. Structural heterogeneity creates leverage points - highly connected hubs adopt protection due to amplified risk, catalyzing cooperation. Cost heterogeneity creates weakest links - low-risk individuals free-ride and act as disease reservoirs, undermining cooperation. Heterogeneity is double-edged: influence asymmetry facilitates cooperation, motivation asymmetry degrades it.
candidates.mechanism_2: When effective interactions among system components compress into low-dimensional interaction space, global organization is governed by geometric constraints rather than detailed dynamics. Low interaction dimensionality imposes upper bounds on number, separability, and robustness of collective organizations. Many macroscopic organizations are excluded a priori even when locally-compatible interactions exist, shifting explanation from generative mechanisms to structural impossibility.

candidates.mechanism_2: Multi-agent performance is governed by certainty preference: reducing entropy at any stage for any agent is critical for correct solutions. Uncertainty dynamics are largely determined in the first interaction round, establishing baseline entropy that constrains subsequent evolution. Lower base model entropy during initial problem-solving directly benefits multi-agent outcomes, suggesting initial uncertainty sets persistent constraints on collaborative effectiveness.

candidates.title_1: From semantic memory to collective creativity: A generative cognitive foundation for social creativity models
candidates.title_2: Estimating measures of information processing during cognitive tasks using functional magnetic resonance imaging
candidates.mechanism_1: Semantic network topology determines ideational breadth - low modularity yields broader exploration. When agents exchange ideation traces, lower pre-interaction overlap predicts larger stimulation gains. Shared inspiration sources create network-level redundancy as convergent semantic neighborhoods limit diversity of generated ideas.
candidates.mechanism_2: Active information storage (within-region retention), transfer entropy (directed flow), and net synergy (redundancy vs. synergy) quantify information processing. Cross mutual information combines resting-state and task data to address limited samples. AIS increases with cognitive load in fronto-parietal regions; TE reveals enhanced directed flows; net synergy shows global redundancy shift.

candidates.title_1: Effect of higher-order interactions on noisy majority-rule dynamics with random group sizes
candidates.title_2: Microbiome association diversity reflects proximity to the edge of instability
candidates.mechanism_1: Variable group sizes in majority-rule dynamics create heterogeneous influence through effective majority leverage. Rare large-group events can realign substantial population fractions. Critical threshold for independence depends on group-size distribution - heavy-tailed distributions enhance robustness to disorder through occasional macroscopic coordination events.
candidates.mechanism_2: Microbial communities operate near edge of instability - transition from stable fixed-point to chaos controlled by network sparsity and interaction heterogeneity. Effective stability parameter inferred from pairwise covariance distribution width. Healthy gut microbiomes cluster near instability edge with broader associations; dysbiosis shifts toward stable regimes with narrower association distributions.

candidates.title_1: A phenomenological description of critical slowing down at period-doubling bifurcations
candidates.title_2: Metastability and ripening of multi-component liquid mixtures
candidates.mechanism_1: As a system approaches a bifurcation point, convergence to steady state slows dramatically. Near criticality, relaxation time diverges according to universal scaling laws. The system exhibits characteristic critical exponents that govern short-time behavior, asymptotic decay, and crossover between regimes.
candidates.mechanism_2: Multi-component mixtures undergo phase separation through unstable coexistence. Droplets grow via Ostwald ripening with characteristic scaling (radius ~ t^1/3, number ~ n^-2/3). Glass-like relaxation emerges from disordered interactions among components, creating long-lived metastable states. Different wetting angles characterize metastable configurations. Relaxation delay arises from kinetic barriers between metastable states.

candidates.title_1: Threshold Resource Redistribution in Spatially-Structured Kinship Networks
candidates.title_2: Mathematical Modeling of Common-Pool Resources: A Comprehensive Review of Bioeconomics, Strategic Interaction, and Complex Adaptive Systems
candidates.mechanism_1: Threshold-based resource redistribution creates feedback between network structure and resource allocation ability. Agents below threshold solicit help; helpers contribute fractionally based on relatedness. Higher local density and relational closeness emerge as redistribution-dependent survival creates centralized clusters through cooperative resource sharing.
candidates.mechanism_2: Paradigm shift from static optimization to dynamic resilience in commons management. Early deterministic bioeconomic models established individual-collective efficiency tension. Ostrom turn integrated institutional monitoring and sanctions into game theory. Evolutionary dynamics and behavioral economics relaxed rationality. Stochastic models capture spatial heterogeneity and noise-induced regime shifts with early warning signals.

candidates.title_1: Intermittent precipitation and spatial Allee effects drive irregular vegetation patterns in semiarid ecosystems
candidates.title_2: Full-Covariance Chemical Langevin Predator--Prey Diffusion with Absorbing Boundaries
candidates.mechanism_1: Plants facilitate neighboring growth through local resource modification. Facilitation competes with resource competition. When precipitation is intermittent, facilitation-competition balance creates spatial vegetation patterns. Below threshold density, vegetation collapses due to weakened facilitation (spatial Allee effect).
candidates.mechanism_2: Predation creates event-level coupling through biomass conversion: predation-conversion increment (-1,+1) induces strictly negative cross-covariance between prey and predator populations. This mechanistic coupling cannot be captured by diagonal (independent) noise. The coupled dynamics arise from the irreducible stochastic structure of predation events, where prey loss simultaneously causes predator gain, creating intrinsic negative correlation in population fluctuations.

candidates.title_1: Dimensional Peeking for Low-Variance Gradients in Zeroth-Order Discrete Optimization via Simulation
candidates.title_2: GenAI-Net: A Generative AI Framework for Automated Biomolecular Network Design

Multiple parameter values following same code path share gradient information, reducing variance without introducing bias. Information-per-simulation increases by reusing structural similarities in discrete optimization landscape.
candidates.mechanism_2: Biomolecular network design reverses the typical simulation workflow: instead of checking proposed networks, an agent proposes reactions guided by behavioral specification. Coupling generative proposal with simulation-based evaluation (user-specified objective) produces topologically diverse solutions. The generative component explores reaction space, while simulation evaluates functional fit, enabling automated discovery of networks implementing desired dynamics from specifications.

candidates.title_1: FinEvo: From Isolated Backtests to Ecological Market Games for Multi-Agent Financial Strategy Evolution
candidates.title_2: Manipulation in Prediction Markets: An Agent-based Modeling Experiment
candidates.mechanism_1: Strategy distributions evolve through selection (performance-based survival), innovation (mutation), and environmental perturbation (external shocks). Individual agents adapt using local signals while population composition shifts based on relative fitness. Two-layer adaptation - individual learning plus population-level evolution - determines whether strategies persist, collapse, or form coalitions.
candidates.mechanism_2: High-budget agents (whales) shift market prices proportionally to their capital share. Distortion duration depends on non-whale learning rates and herding intensity. Fast learners correct distortions quickly; herding amplifies and prolongs whale influence as coordinated followers reinforce biased prices even when informed traders exit.

candidates.title_1: Photonic neuromorphic processing with coupled spiking silicon microrings
candidates.title_2: Coarse-graining and stochastic oscillations in a phenomenological model of cell-size homeostasis
candidates.mechanism_1: Coupled microring resonators exhibit nonlinear optical dynamics with internal feedback. Injection power and wavelength control dynamical regimes: analogue, spiking, or bistable responses. Nonlinearities create sharp transitions in dynamical complexity at regime boundaries. Spiking dynamics generate sparse activity patterns. Thermal bistabilities emerge at low power enhancing computational capacity. Power-wavelength phase space determines accessible dynamical states.
candidates.mechanism_2: Cell size feedback operates through size deviations (difference between absolute size and cell-cycle progression). Feedback from size to growth rate and cycle timing creates coupled dynamics. In linear regime, dynamics reduce to stochastically forced harmonic oscillator. Cell-cycle timing and intrinsic fluctuations jointly shape size control strategy. Mechanistic feedback structure may differ from apparent coarse-grained correlations due to noise integration.

candidates.title_1: An attention economy model of co-evolution between content quality and audience selectivity
candidates.title_2: Impact of behavioral heterogeneity on epidemic outcome and its mapping into effective network topologies
candidates.mechanism_1: Seed dormancy as bet-hedging strategy in temporally fluctuating environments. Germination fraction trades off current reproduction against future survival through dormant seed bank. Optimal dormancy level depends on environmental variability - higher variance favors increased dormancy. Multi-year averaging through seed bank buffers against temporal unpredictability.
candidates.mechanism_2: Behavioral heterogeneity with homophily creates resurgence dynamics near critical thresholds: diverse risk responses combined with preferential interaction among similar types produces initial decline followed by secondary surge as low-risk subpopulation becomes infected.

candidates.title_1: Threshold Resource Redistribution in Spatially-Structured Kinship Networks
candidates.title_2: Pairwise is Not Enough: Hypergraph Neural Networks for Multi-Agent Pathfinding
candidates.mechanism_1: When agents fall below a resource threshold, they solicit resources from connected neighbors based on relatedness. Redistribution creates feedback between kinship network structure and reproduction ability. This enables population survival at lower resource densities but increases network heterogeneity and local centralization.
candidates.mechanism_2: Hypergraph attention captures group (beyond pairwise) coordination dynamics in multi-agent pathfinding. Standard GNNs limited to pairwise message passing suffer attention dilution in dense environments where group coordination is critical. Attentional mechanisms over directed hypergraphs explicitly model higher-order interactions, mitigating representational bottleneck and enabling complex coordination where pairwise methods fail.

candidates.title_2: Pairwise is Not Enough: Hypergraph Neural Networks for Multi-Agent Pathfinding

Higher network centrality increases output through strategic complementarities with connected agents. Activity in one domain (scientific) enhances productivity in another domain (technological), but this effect is asymmetric - the reverse direction shows no detectable influence.
candidates.mechanism_2: Hypergraph attention captures group (beyond pairwise) coordination dynamics in multi-agent pathfinding. Attentional mechanisms over directed hypergraphs explicitly model higher-order interactions, mitigating representational bottleneck and enabling complex coordination where pairwise methods fail.

candidates.mechanism_2: Higher-order network structure (beyond pairwise) shapes imitation dynamics through group-dependent adoption rates. Information diversity achieved through structured sampling from local neighborhoods. Adoption probability depends on group composition and size, not just neighbor count. Network hypergraph structure determines equilibrium strategy distributions through sampling bias.

candidates.title_1: Intermittent precipitation and spatial Allee effects drive irregular vegetation patterns in semiarid ecosystems
candidates.title_2: Greedy Routing Reachability Games
candidates.mechanism_1: Intermittent resource pulses interact with positive density dependence (Allee effects) to generate irregular spatial clusters. During favorable pulses, local facilitation enables patch expansion; during scarcity, neighborhood density determines survival. Resilience emerges from spatial covariance and local density rather than total biomass.
candidates.mechanism_2: Temporal niche differentiation through phenotypic plasticity in circadian rhythms enables species coexistence. Phase-locking of coupled oscillators creates temporal resource partitioning. Plasticity allows dynamic adjustment of activity timing based on competitor presence. Coexistence emerges when plastic responses generate sufficient temporal separation in resource use patterns.

candidates.title_1: A theory for coexistence and selection of branched actin networks in a shared and finite pool of monomers
candidates.title_2: Thermodynamic cost-controllability tradeoff in metabolic currency coupling
candidates.mechanism_1: Multiple branched actin networks compete for shared monomer pool. Network growth locally depletes monomers creating negative feedback between network density and growth rate. Local depletion couples network growth rates through shared resource. Under weak competition, networks coexist at steady state. Under strong competition, selection replaces coexistence - fastest-growing network excludes others. Competition strength determined by monomer availability and consumption rates.
candidates.mechanism_2: Controllability-efficiency tradeoff in coupled resource management: independent regulation of multiple coupled resources requires balanced abundances to prevent cross-interference, but balanced states incur higher thermodynamic costs through increased entropy production.

candidates.title_1: Thermodynamic Limits of Physical Intelligence
candidates.title_2: Thermodynamic Origin of Degree-Day Scaling in Phase-Change Systems
candidates.mechanism_1: Local monomer depletion creates negative feedback between network density and growth. Epiplexity (structural information encoding) and empowerment (control capacity) provide recognition vs. control axes for physical intelligence. Landauer-scale closed-cycle benchmarks require explicit boundary-closure and reset assumptions - without charging for external low-entropy resources, information gain and dissipation decouple.
candidates.mechanism_2: Phase transitions impose topological constraints that mask energetic fluctuations. Introducing a latent temperature (counterfactual unconstrained trajectory) resolves information loss. Energy conservation enforces duality: total latent heat dissipated equals accumulated exceedance of latent temperature above melting point. This duality is mathematically equivalent to Wasserstein-1 distance (optimal transport) between latent and observed trajectories, with phase change emerging as transport that projects continuous energy variability onto constrained thermodynamic boundaries.

candidates.title_1: Threshold Resource Redistribution in Spatially-Structured Kinship Networks
candidates.title_2: FinEvo: From Isolated Backtests to Ecological Market Games for Multi-Agent Financial Strategy Evolution
candidates.mechanism_1: Threshold-based resource redistribution creates feedback between network structure and resource allocation ability. Agents below threshold solicit help; helpers contribute fractionally based on relatedness. Higher local density and relational closeness emerge as redistribution-dependent survival creates centralized clusters through cooperative resource sharing.
candidates.mechanism_2: Strategy distributions evolve through selection (performance-based survival), innovation (mutation), and environmental perturbation (external shocks). Individual agents adapt using local signals while population composition shifts based on relative fitness. Two-layer adaptation - individual learning plus population-level evolution - determines whether strategies persist, collapse, or form coalitions.

candidates.title_1: Stable Time Series Prediction of Enterprise Carbon Emissions Based on Causal Inference
candidates.title_2: Causal Online Learning of Safe Regions in Cloud Radio Access Networks
candidates.mechanism_1: Causal stable features (robust to external perturbations, stable long-term effects) extracted from multi-environment samples across policies and regions. Risk consistency constraints identify invariant causal relationships unaffected by distribution shifts. Adaptive normalization and sample reweighting dynamically correct temporal non-stationarity from economic fluctuations and policy transitions.
candidates.mechanism_2: Safe operating regions are learned through two-phase online process: passive inference phase (causal inference + Gaussian process regression constructs initial safe region from observations) followed by intervention phase (active Bayesian learning gradually expands region). Convergence to full safe region is proven, with specified probability that learned region remains safe. Passive-to-active transition balances safety (conservative initial estimates) with exploration (gradual expansion).

candidates.title_1: Heterogeneity dominates irreversibility in random Markov models
candidates.title_2: Phase Transitions in Unsupervised Feature Selection
candidates.mechanism_1: Markov dynamics combine heterogeneity and asymmetry (broken detailed balance). Heterogeneity parameter controls transition rate variability. Asymmetry parameter controls forward-backward correlation. Critical locus emerges where relaxation times diverge. Entropy production and predictive information depend strongly on heterogeneity but weakly on asymmetry. Near criticality, small heterogeneity changes cause large dynamical shifts.
candidates.mechanism_2: Phase transition between constrained (glass-like) and unconstrained (liquid-like) regimes identifies minimal informative feature sets: critical feature count where order-parameter distributions shift from bimodal to unimodal marks saturation of downstream task performance.

candidates.title_1: Effect of higher-order interactions on noisy majority-rule dynamics with random group sizes

Critical threshold for independence depends on group-size distribution - heavy-tailed distributions enhance robustness to disorder through occasional macroscopic coordination events.
candidates.mechanism_2: Population-level inference with uncertainty-aware fusion decouples global dynamics from individual variability: clustering behaviorally similar entities, encoding mechanistic priors, and fusing uncertain predictions at cluster level enables scalable simulation.

candidates.mechanism_2: Controllability-efficiency tradeoff in coupled resource management: independent regulation of multiple coupled resources requires balanced abundances to prevent cross-interference, but balanced states incur higher thermodynamic costs through increased entropy production.

candidates.title_2: Decaying Sensitivity of the Zero Solution for a Class of Nonlinear Optimal Control Problems

Metapopulation capacity generalizes to non-uniform local extinction rates. Stochasticity from finite carrying capacities yields reduced one-dimensional description with universal finite-size scaling laws for extinction times. Homogeneous environments require fine-tuned marginally stable coexistence to avoid monodominance.
candidates.mechanism_2: Localized perturbations in graph-structured systems induce optimal trajectories that decay exponentially with graph distance from perturbation source. Spatial decay arises from interaction topology: influences propagate through network edges but attenuate geometrically with path length. Graph distance acts as effective spatial dimension governing perturbation propagation, with topology imposing decay rate independently of detailed dynamics.

Selection governed by no-free-lunch theorem - epistemological trade-off between causal mechanism preservation versus predictive power.

candidates.mechanism_2: Species cross-feed through metabolite leakage and uptake. Competitive uptake of leaked chemicals creates coupled population-chemical dynamics. Network structure determines attractor types: fixed points, limit cycles, low-dimensional chaos, or high-dimensional chaos. High-dimensional chaos enables coexistence beyond competitive exclusion limits through intermittent switching among quasi-stationary states. Chemical dynamics explore high-dimensional space while populations switch intermittently.

candidates.title_1: Intelligent Control of Transportation Flow in Physarum Networks
candidates.title_2: Minimal-Action Discrete Schrödinger Bridge Matching for Peptide Sequence Design

Flow patterns optimize based on nutrient source locations. Network adapts topology through tube reinforcement when flow is high and tube degradation when flow is low. This creates an intelligent search for optimal transport paths through flow-structure feedback.
candidates.mechanism_2: Controlled transport relative to informed reference process yields low-action paths through high-likelihood regions: defining generation as deviation from biologically-informed baseline keeps intermediate states plausible throughout trajectory.

The coupled dynamics arise from the irreducible stochastic structure of predation events, where prey loss simultaneously causes predator gain, creating intrinsic negative correlation in population fluctuations.

candidates.title_2: Multi-Scale Global-Instance Prompt Tuning for Continual Test-time Adaptation in Medical Image Segmentation

candidates.mechanism_2: Multi-scale adaptation combining global domain knowledge and instance-specific adjustments prevents error accumulation in continual learning: global prompts capture broad patterns for anti-forgetting, instance prompts adapt dynamically to local variations.

candidates.title_1: Compartmental-reaction diffusion framework for microscale dynamics of extracellular serotonin in brain tissue
candidates.title_2: Metastability and ripening of multi-component liquid mixtures
candidates.mechanism_1: Serotonin released from varicosities diffuses through extracellular space. Diffusion couples neighboring varicosities into microdomains. Uptake kinetics (reuptake) removes serotonin creating concentration gradients. Firing frequency, geometry, and uptake shape spatial serotonin reservoirs. Local versus volume transmission determined by diffusive coupling strength.
candidates.mechanism_2: Multi-component mixtures undergo phase separation through unstable coexistence. Droplets grow via Ostwald ripening with characteristic scaling (radius ~ t^1/3, number ~ n^-2/3). Glass-like relaxation emerges from disordered interactions among components, creating long-lived metastable states. Different wetting angles characterize metastable configurations. Relaxation delay arises from kinetic barriers between metastable states.

candidates.title_1: Discrete dynamical systems with scaling and inversion symmetries
candidates.title_2: Analytical and numerical study of a parametrically excited 2DOF oscillator with nonlinear restoring magnetic force and rotating rectangular rod
candidates.mechanism_1: System state evolves discretely through iterated function. Scaling symmetry preserves dynamics under magnification/contraction. Near fixed points, small perturbations grow exponentially (positive Lyapunov exponent) causing sensitive dependence. Trajectories confined to fractal attractor with non-integer dimension. Chaotic regime characterized by scaling laws and self-similarity across scales.
candidates.mechanism_2: Time-periodic stiffness variation induces parametric excitation in coupled components. Nonlinear restoring forces and friction interact to produce a spectrum of dynamic responses including periodic, quasi-periodic, and chaotic behaviors. System parameters (stiffness degree, mass symmetry, friction) determine stability boundaries and response amplitude.

Heterogeneity is double-edged: influence asymmetry facilitates cooperation, motivation asymmetry degrades it.

Connectivity-driven transition introduces coherence timescales and weak path-dependence into otherwise memoryless exploration. Network dynamics alone soften combinatorial feasibility barriers without requiring specific biochemistry.

candidates.title_1: Learning virulence-transmission relationships using causal inference
candidates.title_2: How adaptation to food resources and death rates shape oscillatory dynamics in a microbial population
candidates.mechanism_1: Pathogen virulence (harm to host) causally influences transmission rate (spread to new hosts). Increased virulence may increase transmission initially but reduces host mobility decreasing spread. Trade-off creates optimal virulence level maximizing transmission. Evolutionary dynamics drive virulence toward this optimum. Past virulence predicts future transmission but not vice versa (directional causality).
candidates.mechanism_2: Microbes adapt to food supply while experiencing death. Oscillations emerge when adaptation timescale exceeds death timescale. Consumer-resource dynamics couple population growth to substrate replenishment. Multiple timescale interactions determine stability - slow adaptation relative to death enables oscillatory behavior. Necromass recycling and complementary food sources dampen oscillations by facilitating growth.

candidates.title_2: Muon in Associative Memory Learning: Training Dynamics and Scaling Laws

This peer comparison mechanism affects equilibrium asset prices through aggregated strategic adjustments.
candidates.mechanism_2: Local monomer depletion from network growth creates negative feedback between network density and growth rate. Higher density causes faster monomer consumption and slower growth. Multiple networks sharing finite monomer pool reach steady states through self-regulation. Under strong competition, coexistence transitions to selection.
