candidates.mechanism_2: Environmental state dominates progression dynamics over intrinsic mutation rates in spatially structured systems: supportive environments amplify weak growth signals into invasive spread, while inhibitory environments suppress even high-mutation populations.

candidates.title_1: Photonic neuromorphic processing with coupled spiking silicon microrings
candidates.title_2: On the occupation measure of evolution models with vanishing mutations
candidates.mechanism_1: Coupled microring resonators exhibit nonlinear optical dynamics with internal feedback. Injection power and wavelength control dynamical regimes: analogue, spiking, or bistable responses. Nonlinearities create sharp transitions in dynamical complexity at regime boundaries. Spiking dynamics generate sparse activity patterns. Thermal bistabilities emerge at low power enhancing computational capacity. Power-wavelength phase space determines accessible dynamical states.
candidates.mechanism_2: Collective oscillations in many-body systems mediate nonlinear wave mixing without requiring strong single-particle nonlinearity. Coherent many-body response creates effective nonlinearity through collective mode coupling. Weak individual interactions amplified by collective dynamics generate strong wave mixing. Effective interaction strength scales with system size or coupling density.

candidates.title_1: TKG-Thinker: Towards Dynamic Reasoning over Temporal Knowledge Graphs via Agentic Reinforcement Learning
candidates.title_2: Piecewise Deterministic Markov Processes for Bayesian Inference of PDE Coefficients
candidates.mechanism_1: Dual-stage learning: supervised bootstrapping followed by reinforcement-based policy refinement. First stage (supervised fine-tuning) instills core planning capabilities via demonstration data (chain-of-thought). Second stage (reinforcement learning) refines decision policies through dynamic environment interaction using multi-dimensional rewards, enabling autonomous adaptation to complex temporal constraints beyond static supervision coverage.
candidates.mechanism_2: Surrogate-assisted proposal generation with dynamic correction bounds enables efficient exploration when exact evaluations are expensive: surrogate provides cheap proposals, dynamic offset enforcement maintains correctness.

candidates.title_1: Intelligent Control of Transportation Flow in Physarum Networks
candidates.title_2: AbFlow : End-to-end Paratope-Centric Antibody Design by Interaction Enhanced Flow Matching
candidates.mechanism_1: Physarum network morphology responds to environmental stimuli by expanding or retracting tubes. Cytoplasmic flow bidirectionally transports nutrients through the network. Flow patterns optimize based on nutrient source locations. Network adapts topology through tube reinforcement when flow is high and tube degradation when flow is low. This creates an intelligent search for optimal transport paths through flow-structure feedback.
candidates.mechanism_2: End-to-end generative design with multi-scale geometric guidance via optimal transport. Flow-matching framework generates full-atom structures while simultaneously exploiting antigen-specific surface geometry to jointly optimize local binding interface and global structural integrity. Surface-enhanced equivariant network propagates geometric constraints from binding site across scales.

candidates.title_1: Multiple timescales in collective motion: daily and intraday upstream fish migration focusing on Feller condition
candidates.title_2: Effect of higher-order interactions on noisy majority-rule dynamics with random group sizes
candidates.mechanism_1: The ratio between diffusion and drift (Feller condition) determines qualitative migration properties. High diffusion relative to drift creates randomized, intermittent movement patterns. Low ratio produces more deterministic, continuous movement. This ratio acts as a control parameter governing timescale-dependent behavioral transitions.
candidates.mechanism_2: Variable group sizes in majority-rule dynamics create heterogeneous influence through effective majority leverage. Rare large-group events can realign substantial population fractions. Critical threshold for independence depends on group-size distribution - heavy-tailed distributions enhance robustness to disorder through occasional macroscopic coordination events.

candidates.title_1: Decoupling Variance and Scale-Invariant Updates in Adaptive Gradient Descent for Unified Vector and Matrix Optimization
candidates.title_2: All-Atom GPCR-Ligand Simulation via Residual Isometric Latent Flow
candidates.mechanism_1: Decomposing AdaGrad into variance adaptation and scale-invariant terms creates unified framework bridging vector-based and matrix spectral optimization. Variance adaptation improves blockwise smoothness for faster convergence. Decoupling enables seamless transition from coordinate-wise adaptation (Adam) to spectral descent (Muon) by separating second-order correction from coordinate scaling.
candidates.mechanism_2: Residual dynamics modeling via decoupling static topology from temporal fluctuations. System learns isometric latent representation preserving geometric constraints (static topology), then models temporal evolution via relative displacements anchored to initial structure rather than absolute coordinates. Separates invariant structural relationships from dynamic conformational changes, improving computational efficiency while maintaining physical fidelity.

candidates.title_1: The impact of heterogeneity on the co-evolution of cooperation and epidemic spreading in complex networks
candidates.title_2: Controlling extreme events in neuronal networks: A single driving signal approach
candidates.mechanism_1: Cooperation and disease transmission coevolve through network structure. Structural heterogeneity creates leverage points - highly connected hubs adopt protection due to amplified risk, catalyzing cooperation. Cost heterogeneity creates weakest links - low-risk individuals free-ride and act as disease reservoirs, undermining cooperation. Heterogeneity is double-edged: influence asymmetry facilitates cooperation, motivation asymmetry degrades it.
candidates.mechanism_2: Single driving signal targeting one network node suppresses extreme events network-wide through dominance mechanism. Suppression occurs via frequency decoupling - driven neuron breaks from collective proto-event frequency dynamics, disrupting synchronized extreme event generation. Larger driven subpopulation enables earlier control onset, showing scaling advantage.

candidates.title_1: Thermalization in classical systems with discrete phase space
candidates.title_2: Full-Covariance Chemical Langevin Predator--Prey Diffusion with Absorbing Boundaries
candidates.mechanism_1: Local ergodicity in subsystems, rather than global ergodicity, enables thermalization. Subsystem dynamics appear pseudorandom due to local interactions. Statistical properties of observables emerge from this effective local randomization without requiring the entire system to be ergodic.
candidates.mechanism_2: Predation creates event-level coupling through biomass conversion: predation-conversion increment (-1,+1) induces strictly negative cross-covariance between prey and predator populations. This mechanistic coupling cannot be captured by diagonal (independent) noise. The coupled dynamics arise from the irreducible stochastic structure of predation events, where prey loss simultaneously causes predator gain, creating intrinsic negative correlation in population fluctuations.

candidates.title_1: How adaptation to food resources and death rates shape oscillatory dynamics in a microbial population
candidates.title_2: A theory for coexistence and selection of branched actin networks in a shared and finite pool of monomers
candidates.mechanism_1: Microbes adapt to food supply while experiencing death. Oscillations emerge when adaptation timescale exceeds death timescale. Consumer-resource dynamics couple population growth to substrate replenishment. Multiple timescale interactions determine stability - slow adaptation relative to death enables oscillatory behavior. Necromass recycling and complementary food sources dampen oscillations by facilitating growth.
candidates.mechanism_2: Local monomer depletion from network growth creates negative feedback between network density and growth rate. Higher density causes faster monomer consumption and slower growth. Multiple networks sharing finite monomer pool reach steady states through self-regulation. Under strong competition, coexistence transitions to selection.

candidates.title_1: Technology Adoption and Network Externalities in Financial Systems: A Spatial-Network Approach
candidates.title_2: A theory for coexistence and selection of branched actin networks in a shared and finite pool of monomers
candidates.mechanism_1: Technology adoption spreads through spatial and network channels. Spatial spillovers and network externalities interact multiplicatively - nearby adoption and connected peer adoption amplify each other. Cumulative adoption pressure accumulates along stochastic paths through spatial-network space. Network position amplifies or dampens spatial effects, creating non-linear adoption dynamics.
candidates.mechanism_2: Multiple branched actin networks compete for shared monomer pool. Network growth locally depletes monomers creating negative feedback between network density and growth rate. Local depletion couples network growth rates through shared resource. Under weak competition, networks coexist at steady state. Under strong competition, selection replaces coexistence - fastest-growing network excludes others. Competition strength determined by monomer availability and consumption rates.

candidates.title_1: Distributed delay stabilizes bistable genetic networks
candidates.title_2: Thermodynamic Limits of Physical Intelligence
candidates.mechanism_1: Protein production involves delayed multi-step process (transcription, translation, folding, oligomerization). Delay is distributed (noisy) due to stochastic process durations. Increasing delay noise dramatically stabilizes metastable states in bistable circuits. Mean residence times in metastable states increase with delay distribution width. Distributed delay prevents unwanted switching caused by small fluctuations while allowing controlled transitions.
candidates.mechanism_2: Local monomer depletion creates negative feedback between network density and growth. Epiplexity (structural information encoding) and empowerment (control capacity) provide recognition vs. control axes for physical intelligence. Landauer-scale closed-cycle benchmarks require explicit boundary-closure and reset assumptions - without charging for external low-entropy resources, information gain and dissipation decouple.

candidates.title_1: Discrete dynamical systems with scaling and inversion symmetries
candidates.title_2: Cell size control in bacteria is modulated through extrinsic noise, single-cell- and population-growth
candidates.mechanism_1: System state evolves discretely through iterated function. Scaling symmetry preserves dynamics under magnification/contraction. Near fixed points, small perturbations grow exponentially (positive Lyapunov exponent) causing sensitive dependence. Trajectories confined to fractal attractor with non-integer dimension. Chaotic regime characterized by scaling laws and self-similarity across scales.
candidates.mechanism_2: Cell size fluctuates due to noisy growth rates and size-dependent division noise. Size homeostasis mechanisms compensate for fluctuations through size control strategies. Population dynamics alter size distributions compared to single lineages - exponential population growth changes the effective size control measured in constant-volume experiments. Extrinsic growth noise and population structure jointly determine observed size distributions.

candidates.title_1: Muon in Associative Memory Learning: Training Dynamics and Scaling Laws
candidates.title_2: Unveiling Scaling Behaviors in Molecular Language Models: Effects of Model Size, Data, and Representation
candidates.mechanism_1: Sign-based gradient transformation equalizes learning rates across hierarchical frequency components by removing magnitude dependence, eliminating bottlenecks from low-frequency modes and enabling exponentially faster convergence.
candidates.mechanism_2: Scaling behavior depends jointly on model capacity, training data volume, and input representation structure: different representations yield different scaling exponents, making representation choice as critical as model size for performance.

candidates.title_1: Graph-Based Audits for Meek Single Transferable Vote Elections
candidates.title_2: Minimal-Action Discrete Schrödinger Bridge Matching for Peptide Sequence Design
candidates.mechanism_1: Constraining process trajectories to fixed subgraph of possibility space enables efficient verification without full enumeration: defining acceptable path subgraph and verifying containment cheaper than exploring all possibilities.
candidates.mechanism_2: Controlled transport relative to informed reference process yields low-action paths through high-likelihood regions: defining generation as deviation from biologically-informed baseline keeps intermediate states plausible throughout trajectory.

candidates.title_1: Mathematical Modeling of Common-Pool Resources: A Comprehensive Review of Bioeconomics, Strategic Interaction, and Complex Adaptive Systems
candidates.title_2: Division of labor enables efficient collective decision-making under uncertainty
candidates.mechanism_1: Paradigm shift from static optimization to dynamic resilience in commons management. Early deterministic bioeconomic models established individual-collective efficiency tension. Ostrom turn integrated institutional monitoring and sanctions into game theory. Evolutionary dynamics and behavioral economics relaxed rationality. Stochastic models capture spatial heterogeneity and noise-induced regime shifts with early warning signals.
candidates.mechanism_2: Division of labor emerges from heterogeneous response thresholds combined with task-dependent positive feedback. Individuals with low thresholds specialize in corresponding tasks as they activate more frequently and self-reinforce. Threshold distribution determines whether population exhibits generalism or specialized subpopulations. Decentralized coordination through threshold heterogeneity without central control.

candidates.title_1: OdysseyArena: Benchmarking Large Language Models For Long-Horizon, Active and Inductive Interactions
candidates.title_2: Piecewise Deterministic Markov Processes for Bayesian Inference of PDE Coefficients
candidates.mechanism_1: Inductive rule discovery from interaction experience vs deductive execution from explicit rules. Agent must autonomously infer latent transition dynamics through long-horizon active exploration rather than following pre-specified environmental laws. Requires building internal model of state evolution from observed trajectories, enabling strategic foresight and coherent planning over extended interaction sequences.
candidates.mechanism_2: Surrogate-assisted proposal generation with dynamic correction bounds enables efficient exploration when exact evaluations are expensive: surrogate provides cheap proposals, dynamic offset enforcement maintains correctness.

candidates.title_1: Effect of higher-order interactions on noisy majority-rule dynamics with random group sizes
candidates.title_2: Advancing Opinion Dynamics Modeling with Neural Diffusion-Convection-Reaction Equation
candidates.mechanism_1: Variable group sizes in majority-rule dynamics create heterogeneous influence through effective majority leverage. Rare large-group events can realign substantial population fractions. Critical threshold for independence depends on group-size distribution - heavy-tailed distributions enhance robustness to disorder through occasional macroscopic coordination events.
candidates.mechanism_2: Opinion evolution emerges from three coupled processes: diffusion (local influence spreading), convection (directional opinion flow driven by global trends), and reaction (endogenous opinion change). Each level operates at distinct scales—local peer-to-peer, global population-wide, and individual internal—that interact through multi-scale coupling. The system exhibits dynamics from interacting particle theory projected onto opinion space.

candidates.title_1: Taming multiparty entanglement at measurement-induced phase transitions
candidates.title_2: Entanglement improves coordination in distributed systems
candidates.mechanism_1: Quantum systems undergo measurement-induced phase transitions when unitary evolution competes with measurements. Below critical measurement rate, volume-law entanglement dominates. Above critical rate, area-law entanglement emerges. Measurement rate acts as control parameter for phase transition. Competing dynamics create distinct entanglement phases. Multiparty entanglement structure differs across phases.
candidates.mechanism_2: Non-local quantum correlations enable superior coordination in distributed systems with convex reward functions: instantaneous shared randomness from entanglement avoids communication latency costs when longer uninterrupted processing yields superlinear rewards.

candidates.title_1: From semantic memory to collective creativity: A generative cognitive foundation for social creativity models
candidates.title_2: Mean-Field Price Formation on Trees with a Network of Relative Performance Concerns
candidates.mechanism_1: Individual semantic network topology determines ideational breadth. When agents exchange ideation traces, lower initial overlap predicts larger stimulation gains. Shared inspiration sources create network-level redundancy, forming feedback between individual cognitive structure and collective outcomes.
candidates.mechanism_2: Agents care about their performance relative to connected peers. Relative performance concerns create strategic interdependencies through network links. Risk-taking behavior adjusts based on peer comparisons. Network topology determines how competitive pressures propagate. This peer comparison mechanism affects equilibrium asset prices through aggregated strategic adjustments.

candidates.title_1: All-Atom GPCR-Ligand Simulation via Residual Isometric Latent Flow
candidates.title_2: Thermodynamic Origin of Degree-Day Scaling in Phase-Change Systems
candidates.mechanism_1: Residual dynamics modeling via decoupling static topology from temporal fluctuations. System learns isometric latent representation preserving geometric constraints (static topology), then models temporal evolution via relative displacements anchored to initial structure rather than absolute coordinates. Separates invariant structural relationships from dynamic conformational changes, improving computational efficiency while maintaining physical fidelity.
candidates.mechanism_2: Phase transitions impose topological constraints that mask energetic fluctuations. Introducing a latent temperature (counterfactual unconstrained trajectory) resolves information loss. Energy conservation enforces duality: total latent heat dissipated equals accumulated exceedance of latent temperature above melting point. This duality is mathematically equivalent to Wasserstein-1 distance (optimal transport) between latent and observed trajectories, with phase change emerging as transport that projects continuous energy variability onto constrained thermodynamic boundaries.

candidates.title_1: Piecewise Deterministic Markov Processes for Bayesian Inference of PDE Coefficients
candidates.title_2: Optimization is Not Enough: Why Problem Formulation Deserves Equal Attention
candidates.mechanism_1: Surrogate-assisted proposal generation with dynamic correction bounds enables efficient exploration when exact evaluations are expensive: surrogate provides cheap proposals, dynamic offset enforcement maintains correctness.
candidates.mechanism_2: Sequential optimization respecting variable structure outperforms concurrent optimization ignoring structure: grouping structurally similar variables and optimizing in stages leverages domain knowledge to guide search more effectively.

candidates.title_1: An attention economy model of co-evolution between content quality and audience selectivity
candidates.title_2: Optimal Control Strategies for Epidemic Dynamics: Integrating SIR-SI and Lotka--Volterra Models
candidates.mechanism_1: Seed dormancy as bet-hedging strategy in temporally fluctuating environments. Germination fraction trades off current reproduction against future survival through dormant seed bank. Optimal dormancy level depends on environmental variability - higher variance favors increased dormancy. Multi-year averaging through seed bank buffers against temporal unpredictability.
candidates.mechanism_2: Coupled multi-timescale dynamics with threshold-based control transition. Fast epidemiological process coupled to slow ecological oscillation, where amplitude of slow cycle determines disease persistence via threshold (ecological reproduction number). Natural control sufficient above threshold; below threshold requires engineered intervention to navigate both timescales simultaneously.

candidates.title_1: Division of labor enables efficient collective decision-making under uncertainty
candidates.title_2: Optimal Learning-Rate Schedules under Functional Scaling Laws: Power Decay and Warmup-Stable-Decay
candidates.mechanism_1: Division of labor emerges from heterogeneous response thresholds combined with task-dependent positive feedback. Individuals with low thresholds specialize in corresponding tasks as they activate more frequently and self-reinforce. Threshold distribution determines whether population exhibits generalism or specialized subpopulations. Decentralized coordination through threshold heterogeneity without central control.
candidates.mechanism_2: Phase transition in optimal strategy based on task difficulty regime. System exhibits qualitatively different behaviors (power decay vs warmup-stable-decay) separated by sharp threshold determined by ratio of signal learning rate to noise forgetting capacity. Easy-task regime benefits from gradual decay, hard-task regime requires maintaining peak resources until near completion.

candidates.title_1: A brief review of evolutionary game dynamics in the reinforcement learning paradigm
candidates.title_2: Emulating Aggregate Human Choice Behavior and Biases with GPT Conversational Agents
candidates.mechanism_1: Reinforcement learning paradigm differs from imitation learning by enabling introspective strategy refinement through trial-and-error rather than copying successful neighbors. Individuals learn from environmental feedback and adapt based on personal experience. This resolves discrepancies between theoretical predictions and behavioral experiments in cooperation, trust, and fairness.
candidates.mechanism_2: Cognitive biases shape decision-making through interaction with contextual factors. When cognitive load increases (complex dialogue), pre-existing biases amplify through reduced deliberative capacity. The bias magnitude is context-dependent: simple interactions suppress bias expression, while complex interactions magnify it by consuming cognitive resources that would otherwise moderate biased responses.

candidates.title_1: Heterogeneity dominates irreversibility in random Markov models
candidates.title_2: Impact of behavioral heterogeneity on epidemic outcome and its mapping into effective network topologies
candidates.mechanism_1: Markov dynamics combine heterogeneity and asymmetry (broken detailed balance). Heterogeneity parameter controls transition rate variability. Asymmetry parameter controls forward-backward correlation. Critical locus emerges where relaxation times diverge. Entropy production and predictive information depend strongly on heterogeneity but weakly on asymmetry. Near criticality, small heterogeneity changes cause large dynamical shifts.
candidates.mechanism_2: Behavioral heterogeneity with homophily creates resurgence dynamics near critical thresholds: diverse risk responses combined with preferential interaction among similar types produces initial decline followed by secondary surge as low-risk subpopulation becomes infected.

candidates.title_1: Chaotic Dynamics in Extremal Black Holes: A Challenge to the Chaos Bound
candidates.title_2: Multiple timescales in collective motion: daily and intraday upstream fish migration focusing on Feller condition
candidates.mechanism_1: Particle motion in extremal configurations exhibits positive Lyapunov exponents indicating sensitivity to initial conditions. Chaos persists even at zero temperature. System parameters (spin, charge) modulate chaos strength - increasing one parameter strengthens chaotic behavior while the other weakens it.
candidates.mechanism_2: The ratio between diffusion and drift (Feller condition) determines qualitative migration properties. High diffusion relative to drift creates randomized, intermittent movement patterns. Low ratio produces more deterministic, continuous movement. This ratio acts as a control parameter governing timescale-dependent behavioral transitions.

candidates.title_1: Collaboration for the Bioeconomy -- Evidence from Innovation Output in Sweden, 1970-2021
candidates.title_2: Emergent structures in coupled opinion and network dynamics
candidates.mechanism_1: Firms collaborate forming innovation network. Central firms access diverse knowledge from multiple partners enhancing innovation output. Peripheral firms limited by fewer connections. Network structure (centrality) determines innovation capacity. Successful innovators attract more partners (preferential attachment) reinforcing centrality advantage.
candidates.mechanism_2: Individuals' opinions and network edge weights coevolve through coupled dynamics. Interaction strength depends on opinion distance. Similar opinions strengthen network connections. Connection strength amplifies opinion influence. This creates feedback between opinion convergence and network structure formation. Interaction function form determines emergent structures and stability.

candidates.title_1: Intermittent precipitation and spatial Allee effects drive irregular vegetation patterns in semiarid ecosystems
candidates.title_2: Thermodynamic cost-controllability tradeoff in metabolic currency coupling
candidates.mechanism_1: Intermittent resource pulses interact with positive density dependence (Allee effects) to generate irregular spatial clusters. During favorable pulses, local facilitation enables patch expansion; during scarcity, neighborhood density determines survival. Resilience emerges from spatial covariance and local density rather than total biomass.
candidates.mechanism_2: Controllability-efficiency tradeoff in coupled resource management: independent regulation of multiple coupled resources requires balanced abundances to prevent cross-interference, but balanced states incur higher thermodynamic costs through increased entropy production.

candidates.title_1: A theory for coexistence and selection of branched actin networks in a shared and finite pool of monomers
candidates.title_2: Decaying Sensitivity of the Zero Solution for a Class of Nonlinear Optimal Control Problems
candidates.mechanism_1: Local monomer depletion from network growth creates negative feedback between network density and growth rate. Higher density causes faster monomer consumption and slower growth. Multiple networks sharing finite monomer pool reach steady states through self-regulation. Under strong competition, coexistence transitions to selection.
candidates.mechanism_2: Localized perturbations in graph-structured systems induce optimal trajectories that decay exponentially with graph distance from perturbation source. Spatial decay arises from interaction topology: influences propagate through network edges but attenuate geometrically with path length. Graph distance acts as effective spatial dimension governing perturbation propagation, with topology imposing decay rate independently of detailed dynamics.

candidates.title_1: On the occupation measure of evolution models with vanishing mutations
candidates.title_2: Advancing Opinion Dynamics Modeling with Neural Diffusion-Convection-Reaction Equation
candidates.mechanism_1: Collective oscillations in many-body systems mediate nonlinear wave mixing without requiring strong single-particle nonlinearity. Coherent many-body response creates effective nonlinearity through collective mode coupling. Weak individual interactions amplified by collective dynamics generate strong wave mixing. Effective interaction strength scales with system size or coupling density.
candidates.mechanism_2: Opinion evolution emerges from three coupled processes: diffusion (local influence spreading), convection (directional opinion flow driven by global trends), and reaction (endogenous opinion change). Each level operates at distinct scales—local peer-to-peer, global population-wide, and individual internal—that interact through multi-scale coupling. The system exhibits dynamics from interacting particle theory projected onto opinion space.

candidates.title_1: Analytical and numerical study of a parametrically excited 2DOF oscillator with nonlinear restoring magnetic force and rotating rectangular rod
candidates.title_2: Optimal Control Strategies for Epidemic Dynamics: Integrating SIR-SI and Lotka--Volterra Models
candidates.mechanism_1: Time-periodic stiffness variation induces parametric excitation in coupled components. Nonlinear restoring forces and friction interact to produce a spectrum of dynamic responses including periodic, quasi-periodic, and chaotic behaviors. System parameters (stiffness degree, mass symmetry, friction) determine stability boundaries and response amplitude.
candidates.mechanism_2: Coupled multi-timescale dynamics with threshold-based control transition. Fast epidemiological process coupled to slow ecological oscillation, where amplitude of slow cycle determines disease persistence via threshold (ecological reproduction number). Natural control sufficient above threshold; below threshold requires engineered intervention to navigate both timescales simultaneously.

candidates.title_1: FinEvo: From Isolated Backtests to Ecological Market Games for Multi-Agent Financial Strategy Evolution
candidates.title_2: The Great Filter hypothesis -- a new Great Filter?
candidates.mechanism_1: Strategy distributions evolve through selection (performance-based survival), innovation (mutation), and environmental perturbation (external shocks). Individual agents adapt using local signals while population composition shifts based on relative fitness. Two-layer adaptation - individual learning plus population-level evolution - determines whether strategies persist, collapse, or form coalitions.
candidates.mechanism_2: Resource allocation trade-off between immune repertoire diversity and clone expansion. Broad repertoire enables better pathogen recognition but limits per-clone resources. Focused expansion provides strong response to known pathogens but reduces diversity. Optimal strategy depends on pathogen encounter rate and diversity - high diversity environments favor broad repertoires despite weaker per-clone responses.

candidates.title_1: A Minimal Task Reveals Emergent Path Integration and Object-Location Binding in a Predictive Sequence Model
candidates.title_2: PhysicsAgentABM: Physics-Guided Generative Agent-Based Modeling
candidates.mechanism_1: Action-conditioned sequential prediction enables path integration and dynamic object-location binding for world modeling. Prediction accuracy improves across sequence through in-context learning. Structured representations with flexible binding emerge to support prediction - new bindings learnable late in sequence, out-of-distribution bindings acquirable through sequential exposure.
candidates.mechanism_2: Population-level inference with uncertainty-aware fusion decouples global dynamics from individual variability: clustering behaviorally similar entities, encoding mechanistic priors, and fusing uncertain predictions at cluster level enables scalable simulation.

candidates.title_1: Imperfect Turing Patterns: Diffusiophoretic Assembly of Hard Spheres via Reaction-Diffusion Instabilities
candidates.title_2: GenAI-Net: A Generative AI Framework for Automated Biomolecular Network Design
candidates.mechanism_1: Multi-scale pattern formation via coupled reaction-diffusion and particle assembly. Classical Turing mechanism (single length scale from reaction-diffusion balance) coupled to finite-size particle assembly driven by background chemical gradient (diffusiophoresis) plus particle-particle interactions. Introduces additional control parameters (particle size, Péclet number, interaction strength) creating imperfections, grain textures, and multi-scale structures.
candidates.mechanism_2: Biomolecular network design reverses the typical simulation workflow: instead of checking proposed networks, an agent proposes reactions guided by behavioral specification. Coupling generative proposal with simulation-based evaluation (user-specified objective) produces topologically diverse solutions. The generative component explores reaction space, while simulation evaluates functional fit, enabling automated discovery of networks implementing desired dynamics from specifications.

candidates.title_2: Distributed delay stabilizes bistable genetic networks

candidates.title_2: Emulating Aggregate Human Choice Behavior and Biases with GPT Conversational Agents
candidates.mechanism_1: AI use reduces cultural variance in populations. Under individual selection, agents relying heavily on AI (substitutes) outcompete those using AI as complement, despite reducing variance more. Group selection can favor agents that maintain variance through complementary AI use when group boundaries are strong, creating selection-level competition.
candidates.mechanism_2: Cognitive biases shape decision-making through interaction with contextual factors. The bias magnitude is context-dependent: simple interactions suppress bias expression, while complex interactions magnify it by consuming cognitive resources that would otherwise moderate biased responses.

candidates.title_2: Thermodynamic cost-controllability tradeoff in metabolic currency coupling

candidates.mechanism_2: Controllability-efficiency tradeoff in coupled resource management: independent regulation of multiple coupled resources requires balanced abundances to prevent cross-interference, but balanced states incur higher thermodynamic costs through increased entropy production.

candidates.title_1: Disentangling Causal Importance from Emergent Structure in Multi-Expert Orchestration
candidates.title_2: Crossing the Functional Desert: Cascade-Driven Assembly and Feasibility Transitions in Early Life
candidates.mechanism_1: Expert importance exhibits dual structure: relational importance (routing frequency, interaction centrality) diverges from intrinsic importance (causal influence via gradient attribution). Frequently-routed experts may act as structural hubs with limited functional impact, while sparsely-routed experts can be causally critical. Masking intrinsically-important experts causes disproportionate collapse in interaction topology compared to masking frequent peers, revealing hidden causal dependencies.
candidates.mechanism_2: Functional organization transitions at critical connectivity: below threshold, cascades die locally creating a functional desert (sparse, transient responses); near percolation threshold, system-spanning cascades emerge enabling discriminative responses. Connectivity-driven transition introduces coherence timescales and weak path-dependence into otherwise memoryless exploration. Network dynamics alone soften combinatorial feasibility barriers without requiring specific biochemistry.

candidates.title_1: Pairwise is Not Enough: Hypergraph Neural Networks for Multi-Agent Pathfinding
candidates.title_2: GenAI-Net: A Generative AI Framework for Automated Biomolecular Network Design

Standard GNNs limited to pairwise message passing suffer attention dilution in dense environments where group coordination is critical. Attentional mechanisms over directed hypergraphs explicitly model higher-order interactions, mitigating representational bottleneck and enabling complex coordination where pairwise methods fail.

candidates.title_2: Low-Dimensional Interaction Spaces Impose Geometric Constraints On Collective Organization
candidates.mechanism_1: Token-mediated dependencies create dense inter-component connections. A shock to one component propagates through dependency links causing contagion effects. Network topology and link weights determine the extent and path of cascading failures across the system.
candidates.mechanism_2: When effective interactions among system components compress into low-dimensional interaction space, global organization is governed by geometric constraints rather than detailed dynamics. Low interaction dimensionality imposes upper bounds on number, separability, and robustness of collective organizations. Many macroscopic organizations are excluded a priori even when locally-compatible interactions exist, shifting explanation from generative mechanisms to structural impossibility.

candidates.title_1: Threshold Resource Redistribution in Spatially-Structured Kinship Networks
candidates.title_2: Technology Adoption and Network Externalities in Financial Systems: A Spatial-Network Approach
candidates.mechanism_1: When agents fall below a resource threshold, they solicit resources from connected neighbors based on relatedness. Redistribution creates feedback between kinship network structure and reproduction ability. This enables population survival at lower resource densities but increases network heterogeneity and local centralization.
candidates.mechanism_2: Technology adoption spreads through spatial and network channels. Spatial spillovers and network externalities interact multiplicatively - nearby adoption and connected peer adoption amplify each other. Cumulative adoption pressure accumulates along stochastic paths through spatial-network space. Network position amplifies or dampens spatial effects, creating non-linear adoption dynamics.

candidates.title_1: Strategic Interactions in Science and Technology Networks: Substitutes or Complements?
candidates.title_2: Game-Theoretic and Algorithmic Analyses of Multi-Agent Routing under Crossing Costs
candidates.mechanism_1: An agent's position in a collaboration network determines their productivity. Higher network centrality increases output through strategic complementarities with connected agents. Activity in one domain (scientific) enhances productivity in another domain (technological), but this effect is asymmetric - the reverse direction shows no detectable influence.
candidates.mechanism_2: Crossing cost (product of opposing-direction agent counts) quantifies conflict risk in asynchronous multi-agent routing. Pure Nash equilibria exist when agents minimize individual crossing exposure. Equilibrium emergence dynamics depend on network structure - general case is PLS-complete, but polynomial-time solvable under mild structural conditions.

candidates.title_1: DeXposure-FM: A Time-series, Graph Foundation Model for Credit Exposures and Stability on Decentralized Financial Networks
candidates.title_2: Intermittent precipitation and spatial Allee effects drive irregular vegetation patterns in semiarid ecosystems
candidates.mechanism_1: Token-mediated dependencies create dense inter-component connections. A shock to one component propagates through dependency links causing contagion effects. Network topology and link weights determine the extent and path of cascading failures across the system.
candidates.mechanism_2: Intermittent resource pulses interact with positive density dependence (Allee effects) to generate irregular spatial clusters. During favorable pulses, local facilitation enables patch expansion; during scarcity, neighborhood density determines survival. Resilience emerges from spatial covariance and local density rather than total biomass.

candidates.title_1: Autodiscover: A reinforcement learning recommendation system for the cold-start imbalance challenge in active learning, powered by graph-aware thompson sampling
candidates.title_2: Optimal Learning-Rate Schedules under Functional Scaling Laws: Power Decay and Warmup-Stable-Decay
candidates.mechanism_1: Discounted Thompson Sampling dynamically manages portfolio of query strategies in active learning. Agent balances exploration-exploitation under non-stationary review dynamics where strategy utility changes over time. Graph-aware attention learns relational structure while agent adapts strategy selection, mitigating cold-start failures through bootstrapping discovery from minimal labels.
candidates.mechanism_2: Phase transition in optimal strategy based on task difficulty regime. System exhibits qualitatively different behaviors (power decay vs warmup-stable-decay) separated by sharp threshold determined by ratio of signal learning rate to noise forgetting capacity. Easy-task regime benefits from gradual decay, hard-task regime requires maintaining peak resources until near completion.

candidates.title_1: Controlling extreme events in neuronal networks: A single driving signal approach
candidates.title_2: Impact of seed node position on network robustness under localized attacks
candidates.mechanism_1: A single driving signal applied to one network component suppresses extreme events throughout the system. In coupled components, drive breaks phase-locking between elements. In networked systems, drive disrupts protoevent frequency dynamics causing frequency decoupling that prevents extreme event cascades.
candidates.mechanism_2: Localized damage initiates at a seed node and propagates to neighbors. The structural position of the seed node (local connectivity and topology) amplifies or dampens damage progression. Cumulative link severing during attack progression depends critically on seed node characteristics rather than average network properties.

candidates.title_1: From semantic memory to collective creativity: A generative cognitive foundation for social creativity models
candidates.title_2: Threshold Resource Redistribution in Spatially-Structured Kinship Networks
candidates.mechanism_1: Individual semantic network topology determines ideational breadth. When agents exchange ideation traces, lower initial overlap predicts larger stimulation gains. Shared inspiration sources create network-level redundancy, forming feedback between individual cognitive structure and collective outcomes.
candidates.mechanism_2: When agents fall below a resource threshold, they solicit resources from connected neighbors based on relatedness. Redistribution creates feedback between kinship network structure and reproduction ability. This enables population survival at lower resource densities but increases network heterogeneity and local centralization.

candidates.title_1: DeXposure-FM: A Time-series, Graph Foundation Model for Credit Exposures and Stability on Decentralized Financial Networks
candidates.title_2: Threshold Resource Redistribution in Spatially-Structured Kinship Networks
candidates.mechanism_1: Token-mediated dependencies create dense inter-component connections. A shock to one component propagates through dependency links causing contagion effects. Network topology and link weights determine the extent and path of cascading failures across the system.
candidates.mechanism_2: Threshold-based resource redistribution creates feedback between network structure and resource allocation ability. Agents below threshold solicit help; helpers contribute fractionally based on relatedness. Higher local density and relational closeness emerge as redistribution-dependent survival creates centralized clusters through cooperative resource sharing.

candidates.title_1: Emergent structures in coupled opinion and network dynamics
candidates.title_2: Low-Dimensional Interaction Spaces Impose Geometric Constraints On Collective Organization
candidates.mechanism_1: Individuals' opinions and network edge weights coevolve through coupled dynamics. Interaction strength depends on opinion distance. Similar opinions strengthen network connections. Connection strength amplifies opinion influence. This creates feedback between opinion convergence and network structure formation. Interaction function form determines emergent structures and stability.
candidates.mechanism_2: When effective interactions among system components compress into low-dimensional interaction space, global organization is governed by geometric constraints rather than detailed dynamics. Low interaction dimensionality imposes upper bounds on number, separability, and robustness of collective organizations. Many macroscopic organizations are excluded a priori even when locally-compatible interactions exist, shifting explanation from generative mechanisms to structural impossibility.

candidates.title_1: Allostery Beyond Amplification: Temporal Regulation of Signaling Information
candidates.title_2: Greedy Routing Reachability Games
candidates.mechanism_1: Allosteric regulation modulates enzyme activity temporally rather than just amplifying output. Regulatory state switches affect timing of downstream signaling. Information content in signaling depends on temporal patterns not just abundance. Regulatory switching creates temporal encoding of information. Fast switching increases information transmission while slow switching filters noise.
candidates.mechanism_2: Temporal niche differentiation through phenotypic plasticity in circadian rhythms enables species coexistence. Phase-locking of coupled oscillators creates temporal resource partitioning. Plasticity allows dynamic adjustment of activity timing based on competitor presence. Coexistence emerges when plastic responses generate sufficient temporal separation in resource use patterns.

candidates.title_1: Technology Adoption and Network Externalities in Financial Systems: A Spatial-Network Approach
candidates.title_2: The Architecture of Illusion: Network Opacity and Strategic Escalation
candidates.mechanism_1: Technology adoption spreads through spatial and network channels. Spatial spillovers and network externalities interact multiplicatively - nearby adoption and connected peer adoption amplify each other. Cumulative adoption pressure accumulates along stochastic paths through spatial-network space. Network position amplifies or dampens spatial effects, creating non-linear adoption dynamics.
candidates.mechanism_2: Network-mediated observation bias creates systematic misperception in strategic reasoning. Agents observe only network-local sample biased by position (algorithmic ranking, homophily), not global population. Locality parameter controls observation bias magnitude, creating distorted beliefs about opponent sophistication that drive strategic escalation beyond what accurate global information would produce.

candidates.title_1: Stable Time Series Prediction of Enterprise Carbon Emissions Based on Causal Inference
candidates.title_2: Numerical stationary states for nonlocal Fokker-Planck equations via fixed points of consistency maps
candidates.mechanism_1: Causal stable features (robust to external perturbations, stable long-term effects) extracted from multi-environment samples across policies and regions. Risk consistency constraints identify invariant causal relationships unaffected by distribution shifts. Adaptive normalization and sample reweighting dynamically correct temporal non-stationarity from economic fluctuations and policy transitions.
candidates.mechanism_2: Stationary states (both stable and unstable) are computed via fixed-point iteration of a consistency map derived from the PDE and nonlocal interactions. The method is agnostic to dynamical stability—detecting equilibria regardless of whether they attract or repel trajectories. This separates statics (equilibrium existence) from dynamics (stability), enabling discovery of unstable stationary configurations invisible to time-evolution methods.

candidates.title_1: Optimal Abstractions for Verifying Properties of Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks (KANs)
candidates.title_2: Piecewise Deterministic Markov Processes for Bayesian Inference of PDE Coefficients
candidates.mechanism_1: Piecewise affine abstractions of nonlinear KAN activations enable property verification via MILP encoding. Optimal abstraction balances approximation pieces - too many cause intractability, too few yield uninformative bounds. Dynamic programming at unit level combined with knapsack optimization network-wide minimizes total pieces while guaranteeing error bounds.
candidates.mechanism_2: Surrogate-assisted proposal generation with dynamic correction bounds enables efficient exploration when exact evaluations are expensive: surrogate provides cheap proposals, dynamic offset enforcement maintains correctness.

candidates.title_1: Dimensional Peeking for Low-Variance Gradients in Zeroth-Order Discrete Optimization via Simulation
candidates.title_2: History Is Not Enough: An Adaptive Dataflow System for Financial Time-Series Synthesis
candidates.mechanism_1: Lift sampling granularity from scalar perturbations to equivalence classes (control-flow paths). Multiple parameter values following same code path share gradient information, reducing variance without introducing bias. Information-per-simulation increases by reusing structural similarities in discrete optimization landscape.
candidates.mechanism_2: Adaptive control loop for data curation under distribution shift. System couples data manipulation module with performance monitor, using gradient-based optimization to continuously adjust curation parameters based on downstream task performance, creating feedback between model outcomes and data generation strategy.

candidates.title_1: A phenomenological description of critical slowing down at period-doubling bifurcations
candidates.title_2: Semiclassical Structure of the Advection--Diffusion Spectrum in Mixed Phase Spaces
candidates.mechanism_1: As a system approaches a bifurcation point, convergence to steady state slows dramatically. Near criticality, relaxation time diverges according to universal scaling laws. The system exhibits characteristic critical exponents that govern short-time behavior, asymptotic decay, and crossover between regimes.
candidates.mechanism_2: Coexisting dynamical regimes generate competing mode families with non-uniform spectral gaps and persistent modal competition: regular regions support long-lived coherent modes, chaotic regions produce rapid mixing, and coupling between regions creates intermediate tunneling modes.

candidates.title_1: A phenomenological description of critical slowing down at period-doubling bifurcations
candidates.title_2: Understanding the temperature response of biological systems: Part II -- Network-level mechanisms and emergent dynamics
candidates.mechanism_1: As a system approaches a bifurcation point, convergence to steady state slows dramatically. Near criticality, relaxation time diverges according to universal scaling laws. The system exhibits characteristic critical exponents that govern short-time behavior, asymptotic decay, and crossover between regimes.
candidates.mechanism_2: Individual Arrhenius-like temperature dependence at reaction level transforms into non-Arrhenius scaling, thermal limits, and temperature compensation at network level. Coupled biochemical reactions with temperature-modulated kinetics exhibit emergent system-level temperature response curves that differ from component behaviors. Network coupling creates effective nonlinearities and collective constraints, transforming simple exponential dependencies into complex organism-level thermal responses.

candidates.title_1: Mathematical Modeling of Common-Pool Resources: A Comprehensive Review of Bioeconomics, Strategic Interaction, and Complex Adaptive Systems
candidates.title_2: The Architecture of Illusion: Network Opacity and Strategic Escalation
candidates.mechanism_1: Paradigm shift from static optimization to dynamic resilience in commons management. Early deterministic bioeconomic models established individual-collective efficiency tension. Ostrom turn integrated institutional monitoring and sanctions into game theory. Evolutionary dynamics and behavioral economics relaxed rationality. Stochastic models capture spatial heterogeneity and noise-induced regime shifts with early warning signals.
candidates.mechanism_2: Network-mediated observation bias creates systematic misperception in strategic reasoning. Agents observe only network-local sample biased by position (algorithmic ranking, homophily), not global population. Locality parameter controls observation bias magnitude, creating distorted beliefs about opponent sophistication that drive strategic escalation beyond what accurate global information would produce.

candidates.title_1: Multi-Scale Global-Instance Prompt Tuning for Continual Test-time Adaptation in Medical Image Segmentation
candidates.title_2: Fully Automated Adaptive Parameter Selection for 3-D High-order Nyström Boundary Integral Equation Methods
candidates.mechanism_1: Multi-scale adaptation combining global domain knowledge and instance-specific adjustments prevents error accumulation in continual learning: global prompts capture broad patterns for anti-forgetting, instance prompts adapt dynamically to local variations.
candidates.mechanism_2: Unified adaptive schemes eliminate manual parameter tuning while maintaining accuracy across diverse problem instances: automatic error-driven refinement of resolution and interaction distances adapts to local geometric complexity.

candidates.title_1: Multiple timescales in collective motion: daily and intraday upstream fish migration focusing on Feller condition
candidates.title_2: Decaying Sensitivity of the Zero Solution for a Class of Nonlinear Optimal Control Problems
candidates.mechanism_1: The ratio between diffusion and drift (Feller condition) determines qualitative migration properties. High diffusion relative to drift creates randomized, intermittent movement patterns. Low ratio produces more deterministic, continuous movement. This ratio acts as a control parameter governing timescale-dependent behavioral transitions.
candidates.mechanism_2: Localized perturbations in graph-structured systems induce optimal trajectories that decay exponentially with graph distance from perturbation source. Spatial decay arises from interaction topology: influences propagate through network edges but attenuate geometrically with path length. Graph distance acts as effective spatial dimension governing perturbation propagation, with topology imposing decay rate independently of detailed dynamics.

candidates.title_1: To clean or not to clean: The free-rider problem in sequentially shared resources
candidates.title_2: Structure-aware imitation dynamics on higher-order networks
candidates.mechanism_1: Shared resource use creates a cooperation dilemma with cleaning costs, contamination risk, and social incentives forming competing pressures. Cleaning cost primarily determines stability of altruistic behavior. The system exhibits multi-stability and hysteresis - small parameter changes can cause abrupt shifts between cooperation and free-riding equilibria.
candidates.mechanism_2: Higher-order network structure (beyond pairwise) shapes imitation dynamics through group-dependent adoption rates. Information diversity achieved through structured sampling from local neighborhoods. Adoption probability depends on group composition and size, not just neighbor count. Network hypergraph structure determines equilibrium strategy distributions through sampling bias.

candidates.title_1: Higher-order adaptive behaviors outperform pairwise strategies in mitigating contagion dynamics
candidates.title_2: Impact of behavioral heterogeneity on epidemic outcome and its mapping into effective network topologies
candidates.mechanism_1: Higher-order information creates heterogeneous risk perception targeting structural hubs and high-participation nodes, preventing contagion exploitation of these critical paths at lower social cost than uniform interventions.
candidates.mechanism_2: Behavioral heterogeneity with homophily creates resurgence dynamics near critical thresholds: diverse risk responses combined with preferential interaction among similar types produces initial decline followed by secondary surge as low-risk subpopulation becomes infected.

candidates.title_1: The relationship between R&D spillovers and regional innovation: Licensing patents through royalties and the Stackelberg duopoly with subgame perfect Nash equilibrium
candidates.title_2: Mean-Field Price Formation on Trees with a Network of Relative Performance Concerns
candidates.mechanism_1: R&D spillovers from one entity enhance innovation in neighboring entities. Strategic interactions follow Stackelberg dynamics where leaders and followers reach Nash equilibrium. Highly-qualified employment amplifies spillover effects, creating synergies between different types of R&D investment and regional innovation output.
candidates.mechanism_2: Agents care about their performance relative to connected peers. Relative performance concerns create strategic interdependencies through network links. Risk-taking behavior adjusts based on peer comparisons. Network topology determines how competitive pressures propagate. This peer comparison mechanism affects equilibrium asset prices through aggregated strategic adjustments.

candidates.title_1: FinEvo: From Isolated Backtests to Ecological Market Games for Multi-Agent Financial Strategy Evolution

candidates.title_1: Learning virulence-transmission relationships using causal inference
candidates.title_2: Impact of seed node position on network robustness under localized attacks
candidates.mechanism_1: Pathogen virulence (harm to host) causally influences transmission rate (spread to new hosts). Increased virulence may increase transmission initially but reduces host mobility decreasing spread. Trade-off creates optimal virulence level maximizing transmission. Evolutionary dynamics drive virulence toward this optimum. Past virulence predicts future transmission but not vice versa (directional causality).
candidates.mechanism_2: Localized damage initiates at a seed node and propagates to neighbors. The structural position of the seed node (local connectivity and topology) amplifies or dampens damage progression. Cumulative link severing during attack progression depends critically on seed node characteristics rather than average network properties.

candidates.title_1: Discrete dynamical systems with scaling and inversion symmetries
candidates.title_2: Thermodynamic Limits of Physical Intelligence
candidates.mechanism_1: System state evolves discretely through iterated function. Scaling symmetry preserves dynamics under magnification/contraction. Near fixed points, small perturbations grow exponentially (positive Lyapunov exponent) causing sensitive dependence. Trajectories confined to fractal attractor with non-integer dimension. Chaotic regime characterized by scaling laws and self-similarity across scales.
candidates.mechanism_2: Local monomer depletion creates negative feedback between network density and growth. Epiplexity (structural information encoding) and empowerment (control capacity) provide recognition vs. control axes for physical intelligence. Landauer-scale closed-cycle benchmarks require explicit boundary-closure and reset assumptions - without charging for external low-entropy resources, information gain and dissipation decouple.

candidates.title_1: Thermodynamic Origin of Degree-Day Scaling in Phase-Change Systems
candidates.title_2: A generalized work theorem for stopped stochastic chemical reaction networks
candidates.mechanism_1: Phase transitions impose topological constraints that mask energetic fluctuations. Introducing a latent temperature (counterfactual unconstrained trajectory) resolves information loss. Energy conservation enforces duality: total latent heat dissipated equals accumulated exceedance of latent temperature above melting point. This duality is mathematically equivalent to Wasserstein-1 distance (optimal transport) between latent and observed trajectories, with phase change emerging as transport that projects continuous energy variability onto constrained thermodynamic boundaries.
candidates.mechanism_2: Chemical reaction networks exhibit martingale structure in generalized entropy without requiring detailed balance. Martingale properties emerge directly from reaction propensity structure: the jump process compensated with appropriate drift becomes a zero-mean stochastic process. This enables work theorems for arbitrary stopping times and singular initial conditions, generalizing thermodynamic relations beyond equilibrium systems.

candidates.title_1: Intermittent precipitation and spatial Allee effects drive irregular vegetation patterns in semiarid ecosystems
candidates.title_2: Optimal Control Strategies for Epidemic Dynamics: Integrating SIR-SI and Lotka--Volterra Models
candidates.mechanism_1: Plants facilitate neighboring growth through local resource modification. Facilitation competes with resource competition. When precipitation is intermittent, facilitation-competition balance creates spatial vegetation patterns. Below threshold density, vegetation collapses due to weakened facilitation (spatial Allee effect).
candidates.mechanism_2: Coupled multi-timescale dynamics with threshold-based control transition. Fast epidemiological process coupled to slow ecological oscillation, where amplitude of slow cycle determines disease persistence via threshold (ecological reproduction number). Natural control sufficient above threshold; below threshold requires engineered intervention to navigate both timescales simultaneously.

candidates.title_1: Effect of higher-order interactions on noisy majority-rule dynamics with random group sizes
candidates.title_2: On the occupation measure of evolution models with vanishing mutations
candidates.mechanism_1: Variable group sizes in majority-rule dynamics create heterogeneous influence through effective majority leverage. Rare large-group events can realign substantial population fractions. Critical threshold for independence depends on group-size distribution - heavy-tailed distributions enhance robustness to disorder through occasional macroscopic coordination events.
candidates.mechanism_2: Collective oscillations in many-body systems mediate nonlinear wave mixing without requiring strong single-particle nonlinearity. Coherent many-body response creates effective nonlinearity through collective mode coupling. Weak individual interactions amplified by collective dynamics generate strong wave mixing. Effective interaction strength scales with system size or coupling density.

candidates.title_1: To clean or not to clean: The free-rider problem in sequentially shared resources
candidates.title_2: Cross-feeding yields high-dimensional chaos and coexistence of species beyond exclusion principle
candidates.mechanism_1: Shared resource use creates a cooperation dilemma with cleaning costs, contamination risk, and social incentives forming competing pressures. Cleaning cost primarily determines stability of altruistic behavior. The system exhibits multi-stability and hysteresis - small parameter changes can cause abrupt shifts between cooperation and free-riding equilibria.
candidates.mechanism_2: Species cross-feed through metabolite leakage and uptake. Competitive uptake of leaked chemicals creates coupled population-chemical dynamics. Network structure determines attractor types: fixed points, limit cycles, low-dimensional chaos, or high-dimensional chaos. High-dimensional chaos enables coexistence beyond competitive exclusion limits through intermittent switching among quasi-stationary states. Chemical dynamics explore high-dimensional space while populations switch intermittently.

candidates.title_1: Piecewise Deterministic Markov Processes for Bayesian Inference of PDE Coefficients
candidates.title_2: EGSS: Entropy-guided Stepwise Scaling for Reliable Software Engineering
candidates.mechanism_1: Surrogate-assisted proposal generation with dynamic correction bounds enables efficient exploration when exact evaluations are expensive: surrogate provides cheap proposals, dynamic offset enforcement maintains correctness.
candidates.mechanism_2: Test-time scaling balances efficiency and effectiveness through entropy-guided adaptive search: high-entropy (uncertain) states trigger expanded search, while low-entropy states terminate early. Test-suite augmentation provides robust candidate selection. The framework dynamically adjusts ensemble size based on current uncertainty, avoiding excessive computation in confident regions while allocating resources to ambiguous cases.

candidates.title_1: Uncertainty in Island-based Ecosystem Services and Climate Change
candidates.title_2: Distinguishable spreading dynamics in microbial communities
candidates.mechanism_1: Transmission rate increases with infected density. Recovery rate decreases infection duration. When transmission exceeds recovery (R0>1), epidemic spreads exponentially. Vaccination reduces susceptible population shifting R0 below 1. Spatial heterogeneity creates local pockets where R0 varies.
candidates.mechanism_2: Proliferation limitations determine spreading dynamics. Growth arrest causes superlinear spreading at reduced rate. Pressure-limited growth produces linear constant-speed spreading. Nutrient-limited growth exhibits phase transition: superlinear when nutrient supply is high, sublinear when depleted. Nutrient supply and conversion efficiency determine phase boundary. Spreading rate distinguishes dominant limitation type.

candidates.title_1: Optimal Learning-Rate Schedules under Functional Scaling Laws: Power Decay and Warmup-Stable-Decay
candidates.title_2: Emergence of Superintelligence from Collective Near-Critical Dynamics in Reentrant Neural Fields

System exhibits qualitatively different behaviors (power decay vs warmup-stable-decay) separated by sharp threshold determined by ratio of signal learning rate to noise forgetting capacity. candidates.mechanism_2: Qualitative phase transition via spectral condensation at criticality. Progressive reentrant coupling drives system toward infrared critical regime where extensive band of slow collective modes emerges (spectral condensation), reorganizing dynamics qualitatively. Creates emergent capabilities absent at subcritical regime - transition in kind not degree, regardless of system scale.

candidates.title_1: On the occupation measure of evolution models with vanishing mutations
candidates.title_2: Imperfect Turing Patterns: Diffusiophoretic Assembly of Hard Spheres via Reaction-Diffusion Instabilities
candidates.mechanism_1: Collective oscillations in many-body systems mediate nonlinear wave mixing without requiring strong single-particle nonlinearity. candidates.mechanism_2: Multi-scale pattern formation via coupled reaction-diffusion and particle assembly. Classical Turing mechanism (single length scale from reaction-diffusion balance) coupled to finite-size particle assembly driven by background chemical gradient (diffusiophoresis) plus particle-particle interactions. Introduces additional control parameters (particle size, Péclet number, interaction strength) creating imperfections, grain textures, and multi-scale structures.

candidates.title_1: The impact of heterogeneity on the co-evolution of cooperation and epidemic spreading in complex networks
candidates.title_2: Entanglement improves coordination in distributed systems
candidates.mechanism_1: Cooperation and disease transmission coevolve through network structure. Structural heterogeneity creates leverage points - highly connected hubs adopt protection due to amplified risk, catalyzing cooperation. Cost heterogeneity creates weakest links - low-risk individuals free-ride and act as disease reservoirs, undermining cooperation. Heterogeneity is double-edged: influence asymmetry facilitates cooperation, motivation asymmetry degrades it.
candidates.mechanism_2: Non-local quantum correlations enable superior coordination in distributed systems with convex reward functions: instantaneous shared randomness from entanglement avoids communication latency costs when longer uninterrupted processing yields superlinear rewards.

candidates.mechanism_2: Opinion evolution emerges from three coupled processes: diffusion (local influence spreading), convection (directional opinion flow driven by global trends), and reaction (endogenous opinion change). Each level operates at distinct scales—local peer-to-peer, global population-wide, and individual internal—that interact through multi-scale coupling. The system exhibits dynamics from interacting particle theory projected onto opinion space.

candidates.title_1: Habitat heterogeneity and dispersal network structure as drivers of metacommunity dynamics
candidates.title_2: Structure-aware imitation dynamics on higher-order networks

Network topology encodes dispersal effectiveness through an effective kernel.
